loans.name: Dolores

texts.en: Dolores D.'s main source of income comes from providing motorcycle (or habal-habal) services to local community members. She is 25 years old, married and has one small child. They are from the village of Banisilan, Cotabato. Dolores has been in her business for over three years and earns approximately 8,500 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2010, Dolores joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Dolores is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide the service. This will be her first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to provide service

loans.name: Julia

texts.en:
Julia V. is from the village of Dinas,Sinacaban, Misamis Occidental. She is a 52 year old widowed, with six adult-aged children. To make a living, Julia plants and harvests a variety of vegetables like string beans "kangkong," and squash. Julia has been in business for over 10 years and earns approximately 1,500 PHP a month.

In 2010, Julia joined GDMPC to access financial services to improve her living situation and to engage in business. Julia is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP to purchase fertilizers, such as manure. This loan will be her first from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

-----------------------------
About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: Purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Nelia

texts.en: To make a living, Nelia I. runs a general store selling a variety of different products in her community. She is 36 years old, married and has two school-aged children. They are from the village of Salucong. Nelia has been in her business for over seven years and earns approximately 3,200 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2007, Nelia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Nelia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI which was used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. Nelia is requesting a new loan of 13,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her eighth loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Maricris

texts.en:
Maricris P. is from the village of Guintomoyan, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is 20 years old and married. To make a living, Maricris operates a pedicab transportation service. She has been in business for over two years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Maricris joined GDMPC to access financial services to improve her living situation and to engage in business activities. Maricris has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from GDMPC.  Maricris is requesting a new loan of 4000 PHP to purchase tires and other accessories. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand her business. 

--------------------------------------
About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: Purchase tires and other accessories.

loans.name: Naseem's Group

texts.en:
Naseem lives in Vehari, which is a small city located in Punjab, Pakistan popular for its agricultural industry. She is married to M. R. who has a sweetmeat shop in the market. He sells different varieties of tasty sweetmeats to his customers. Naseem herself is a very caring lady. She spends her time at home and carries out her responsibilities as a housewife and mother well. She is an uneducated lady. She couldn’t receive an education due to the poor financial condition of her family but she doesn’t want the same destiny to befall her kids. That’s why she has enrolled her three children in school and is giving them better education facilities so they can have a future bright and feel proud.  

Naseem has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to help her husband’s business. With the loan, her husband will buy ingredients such as milk, sugar, cooking oil and dried fruits to make sweetmeats.  Naseem is hopeful that this investment will bring a positive change to her husband’s business and his income will increase. 
 
Note: “In the picture, the lady who is raising her hand is Naseem”.

loans.use: To buy ingredients for making & selling sweetmeats

loans.name: Mechel

texts.en:
Mechel A. is from the village of Eastern, Wao, Lanao del Sur. She is 25 years old. Mechel is married and has one infant-aged child. To make a living, Mechel owns & operates a business buying and selling vegetables in the local community. Mechel has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 4,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Mechel joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mechel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional vegetables to sell. Mechel is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Mechel from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory & working capital

loans.name: Vina

To make a living, Vina owns & operates a general store selling a variety of different products in the local community. Vina has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Vina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Vina is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the eighth loan taken out by Vina from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees for her children. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is a 29-year-old married man with a baby.  He lives in Lebanon. He has owned a bird shop since 2000 and he has been working in this occupation for the past 15 years. He is really satisfied with his work because he likes birds with their different types and colors and he says that it brings joy to his heart. And he also says that it brings a good atmosphere to the houses where they will have a good place. Today, he is asking for a loan of $1000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase additional birds to increase his sales and make a good income. In the future, he is planning to expand his business and enlarge his shop into other areas.

loans.use: To purchase additional birds

loans.name: David Mwangi

texts.en:
David Mwangi is 53 years old and married to Fraciah K.. They have three children. He keeps dairy cows and he gets a profit of about 5,500 KES a month. He has been in the business for a period of about five years.

David intends to use his loan to buy feed for the dairy cows and buy an extra calf. He was introduced to KADET by a staff member and is hoping to buy a piece of land to develop. His dream is to be a leading milk supplier in his area and to give his children a quality education.

loans.use: Buy feed for the dairy cow

loans.name: Vaen

texts.en:
Vaen S., a mother of three children, lives in Mea Neak village in Takeo province.  She owns a general store and is able to earn a profit to support her family.  Her husband owns a pump machine and is a farmer who owns a five hectare plot of land to cultivate and sell rice to support their family. 

Vaen wants to buy more pump machines, but does not have enough money.  Vaen is applying for a loan to buy one pump machine.

One of her children helps her sell groceries and the other two are students. Her husband is in the photo with Vaen.

loans.use: Buy a pump machine.

loans.name: Houn's Group

texts.en:
Houn K. is a married woman who lives in Preak Ta Kaov village, Kandal province.  She is the village loan bank president, selected by its nineteen members.  Each member will use their portion of the loan to support their own needs.
     
Houn and her husband, a pig breeding and battery charger, do not have enough money to support themselves.  Houn decided to ask for a loan to buy a battery charging machine to support his business.  They have three school age children who help their parents run both businesses.

loans.use: Buy battery charging machine.

loans.name: Gulfa

texts.en:
Gulfa A. lives in Kyrgyzstan, in Tashkomur city. She is 41. Her spouse works as chief of a building site called “Habitat” in Bishkek city. In this way, he makes 20,000 soms per month. Together the couple has two children who are school pupils. In the course of five years after Gulfa’s husband suggestion, they have started their own business concerning computer services (Xerox, computer games). Because Gulfa earns additional money (her salary is 8,000 soms per month) by working as an engineer at TSP Company, her children help to run this business after their studies. Out of the profits, the family has managed to purchase a lot in Bishkek and have almost built a house. In order to finish building the house and make some repairs, the family needs a loan. In the future Gulfa wants to finish the building, equip it with necessary facilities and obtain a car. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. 

To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To finish building her house

loans.name: Shirley

texts.en:
Shirley A. is from the village of Tinago in Ozamiz City. She is 57 years old and married. She has two adult children. Shirley sells dried fish. She has been engaged in this business for three years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Shirley joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She had successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,900 PHP from PMPC. She is now requesting a new loan of 14,900 PHP to buy more dried fish to sell. This will be Shirley’s fifth loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's living conditions.

About PMPC: 

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.use: To purchase more dried fish to sell

loans.name: Gorret

texts.en:
Gorret N. lives in the Makerere Kikoni neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has four children, all of whom are in school.  

Gorret has a business of charcoal selling. She has been in this business for five years and she works six days out of every week. Gorret sells her products from home, by means of retail.    

Gorret has requested a loan of 500,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy bags of charcoal.   She also generates additional income through frying eatables.

The main business challenges for Gorret include transportation and seasonality. Her goal and aspiration for her business is to become a wholesaler.

Gorret lives in a home that she rents; she has access to electricity but doesn't have access to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees, medication and rent.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal
