loans.name: Chhum's Group

texts.en:
Chhum S., 38, and married is the village bank president, having been selected by its nine members.  They live in Kandal Kaoh village, Kandal province.  Each member will use part of the total loan to support different purpose.

Chhum and her husband are fishermen who are able to earn a good profit by selling fish to support their four children: two are seamstresses in the garment factory and two stay at home and help their parent's businesses.  Chhum will use the loan from AMK to buy fishing nets and a fishing machine.

loans.use: Buy fishing nets and a fishing machine for fishing.

loans.name: Geoffrey

texts.en:
Geoffrey I. M. is 38 years old and married. His wife runs a green grocer and he runs a retail shop in Nairobi's Racecourse estate. The business is located by the the highway and it is well known by the name Real Deal Retail. 

They have three children aged between 6 and 13 years whom they hope to give a quality education to the university level. He sells such items as eggs, juice, biscuits, handkerchiefs, paper bags, tissues, etc. He sells to the local people. He has been in this business for the last five years. He says that this business is profitable and the major challenge he has is the fact that there so many other people in the area doing the same kind of business as his and so customers are spoiled for choice. 

However, he works hard from early morning to late evening to ensure that his business is doing well. He is using his loan of 50,000 Kenyan shillings to add to his stock so he can grow his business, which he eventually hopes will become a big wholesale store. He sees himself becoming a millionaire in the future. He describes himself as hardworking, ambitious and determined.

loans.use: To stock eggs, flour, rice, detergents, mineral water, handkerchiefs, etc.

loans.name: Tusaidiane Group

texts.fr: Kahindo A. est  conseillère du groupe Tusaidiane, âgée de 40 ans, veuve, mère de 6 enfants, tous étudient, son mari  est décédé suite a une longue maladie, elle fait le petit commerce de bois depuis 2004. Elle  commença son business avec son fond propre, plus tard, elle bénéficia du crédit de  Hekima en 2005 de 50$ pour renforcer son business de commerce. Elle expose ses marchandises sur la rue, axe de lave. Elle  vent également de graviers aux constructeurs. Ce nouveau crédit doit lui servir de s’approvisionner  des certaines marchandises notamment les matériaux de construction pour  les écouler dans les chantiers des privés. Elle souhaiterait  construire sa maison et faire scolariser ses enfants orphelins confortablement. En plus, elle ambitionne avoir  une nouvelle moto pour faire le taxi, celle qu’elle détient actuellement est déjà amortie. La cliente Kahindo A. remercie Hekima pour  ses actions en faveur de pauvres veuves exclus de banque classique.  Il sied de signaler que ce groupe Tusaidiane est composé de 17 membres. La  cliente Kahindo A. avait acheté cette moto à partir des bénéfices cumulés de ses activités.
texts.en:
Kahindo A. is the advisor of the group "Tusaidiane". She is 40 years old, a widow and the mother of 6 children, all of whom attend school. Her husband died after a long illness. She started a small business selling wood in 2004. She started the business with her own funds and, later in 2005, was the beneficiary of a $50 loan from the organization Hekima to strengthen her business. She sells her merchandise roadside on the principal route. She also sells gravel to construction workers. With this new loan, she will purchase supplies notably construction materials to sell to deprived work-sites. She hopes to build a home and have the opportunity to educate her orphaned children comfortably. Additionally, her ambition is to have a motorcycle to use as part of a taxi business; she has already fully paid for the motorcycle she currently has. (Kahindo A. purchased the motorcycle with the earnings from her business.) Kahindo A. thanks the organization Hekima for its actions in helping poor widows, unlike a traditional bank. The group Tusaidiane is comprised of 17 members.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Construction materials to sell to deprived work-sites

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Edelita Obut Group

texts.en: Edelita O. is from the village of Maikay, Tudela, Misamis Occidental. She is 33 years old. Edelita is the group leader of a two-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are each responsible for paying back the loan of their fellow group member if she is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Edelita O. Group. Edelita is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Edelita raises pigs for sale. Edelita has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 1,200 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2010, Edelita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Edelita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future. Edelita is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This will be the third loan taken out by Edelita from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to save as a reserve for future emergencies. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: The Kiva borrower is a 34-year-old, single woman living with her parents in Lebanon. She has been working as a farmer for the past 15 years. She used to go with her father to cultivate their land. Her father is not able to work alone anymore, so she has been in charge of their operation since 2000. During this period, she was able to develop her father’s business and start collaborating with large agricultural markets to deliver the harvest. She cultivates different types of fruit and vegetables, according to the season. Today, she is requesting to borrow $1000 to purchase agricultural supplies, such as seeds, for the coming cultivation season.

loans.use: to purchase agricultural supplies such as seeds

loans.name: Sek's Group

texts.en:
Sek S. is the leader of a group loan located in Kaoh Krabei village, Kandal province.  She earns a living by sells Khmer cakes and flour.  Her husband is a farmer.
 
In order to increase their income, to improve their family, Sek decided to ask for a loan to buy more flour to resell.  They have three children: two are seamstresses in a garment factory and the other is a student who also helps staff the businesses.

loans.use: Buy more flour to resell.

loans.name: Farida

texts.en:
Farida M. is a citizen of Tashkomur city, Kyrgyzstan. She is 32 and is married. Her family is rather big: together with her husband she is bringing up three children. The eldest daughter and her son are school pupils; the youngest one is a toddler. 

These business-like parents make their living by having their own workshop “Araket” for sand block manufacturing. All this started because Farida’s husband became interested in sand block production and then concluded that this business would be profitable. For two years now, this business has been the main source of family income. From the profits, they have managed to purchase equipment for sand block manufacturing (200000 soms) and also to obtain a flat (100000 soms). They earn on average 28,000 soms per month.

The family is planning to purchase a used car. They already have some money, but need some extra funds to achieve their aim. Hence they need a loan. In the future the couple want to expand their business and to begin producing glazed tiles.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase a used car

loans.name: Moung's Group

texts.en:
Four people make up this group loan.  Moung S. was selected the group's leader.  They all live in Preak Thmei village, Kandal province.
 
Moung is a banana and flour seller in the local market.  Her husband works as electrician.  They are able to earn a small income to support their family.  In order to increase their income, Moung decided to ask for a loan.  She wants to buy more bananas and flour to sell.  This couple has three school age children, who also help staff their mother's business.

loans.use: Buy more bananas and flour to sell.

loans.name: Zahuran's Group

texts.en:
Zahuran is a resident of Vehari. This is a small city located in Punjab, Pakistan which is famous for its agricultural industry. 

The very talented Zahuran owns & operates a sewing business to generate income for her family. She mainly receives orders from the neighboring region but has now started receiving orders from other areas. This is a result of the high quality of her work which has increased her income. 

Her husband is a tailor and runs a tailoring shop in the market. He has hired a worker who helps him complete his work on time. He pays him on a monthly basis. His shop always get filled with customers and he gets good orders on a regular basis. However, sometimes, the orders list increases and to meet deadlines he and his employee work day and night.
 
Zahuran has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah, for her husband’s business. With the loan, her husband will buy another sewing machine which will be used by his employee. The new machine will bring a positive change to his business as, presently, they have two machines and one is not in good working order.
  
Zahuran is hopeful that, by making this investment,  her husband will be able to increase his income and accept more orders from his customers.

loans.use: To buy another sewing machine for the tailoring business

loans.name: Hadjah

texts.en:
Hadjah N. lives in the Mulago neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is single and has 5 children, all of whom are in school. 

Hadjah has a food vending business. She has been in this business for over 10 years and works 6 days a week. Hadjah sells her products retail at the market. Hadjah has requested a loan of 500,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy baskets of fruit and vegetables like tomatoes, onions and cabbages. She also generates additional income by selling green banana leaves. 

The main business challenges for Hadjah include thieves and seasonality. Her goal for her business is to start sourcing directly from farmers. Hadjah lives in a home that she rents; she has access to electricity and doesn't have access to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees, medication and rent.

loans.use: To buy more baskets of onions, tomatoes and cabbages

loans.name: Innocent

texts.en:
Innocent is a 24-year-old man who is ambitious and hardworking. He lives in a rented house in Fort Portal, Uganda.

For six months now, Innocent has been operating a cinema hall and he confesses to have not met any hurdles so far and the business is steadily growing. His dream is to see it become a big theatre.

Innocent intends to use the loan to purchase a television set for his cinema hall.

loans.use: To purchase a television set for his cinema hall

loans.name: Djamila's Group

texts.en:
Djamila O. is the leader of this group. She is 36 and is married. Her husband supports the family by working as a driver in “Mol Bulak Finance” company in Tokmok. The couple are bringing up two children (a son and a daughter); both of them are pupils. Ten years ago she inherited five animals. Since then, the family has been engaged in cattle breeding. Djamila also works as a warehouse manager in “Arvin” company. During their years of hard work, the couple have managed to increase their cattle stock. The purpose of this loan is to purchase more cattle to further incresae livestock numbers. In the future, Djamila intends to continue increasing cattle stock. 

Ainagul I., 50, is married and has five sons (30, 28, 25, 23, 14). The eldest one lives separately, but is temporarily living with his parents; the second one is married; the next 2 work in Russia, and the youngest one is a schoolboy. The head of the family makes a living by working as an “Interglass” glass-works laborer. The primary family business is cattle breeding. Twenty years ago the couple bought three sheep. They have already managed to increase cattle stock and to buy a car. The loan purpose is to buy 5 sheep to further increase cattle stock. In the future Ainagul is planning to arrange her sons’ weddings and also to purchase a private house.

Upel K., 50, is married to a worker in “Kyrgyz Temir Joldoru” company. The couple have two children; their son contributes to the family income by working as a security guard in a petrol station “Petroleum” while their daughter is a schoolgirl. As well as the individual family members' professions, they have a common business: cattle breeding. In 4 years they have managed to increase cattle stock and to make house repairs. Upel, together with her family, wants to expand further by purchasing 5 sheep. For this purpose they need a loan. 

Elmira K., 33, is married. She is the treasurer of the group. Two years ago her father presented a sheep to his granddaughter (she is a schoolgirl). Since then the family has been engaged in cattle breeding. Elmira’s spouse also earns money by repairing automobiles. He has a service center at home. From their income, the couple have managed to increase cattle stock. They need a loan to obtain 5 sheep. In the future Elmira is planning to open her own shop. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Chrin's Group

texts.en:
This group loan consists of five people.  Chrin N., 35, is its leader. They all live in Svay Prey village, Kandal province.  Each member will use their portion of the loan for different purposes.

Chrin is a widow with a child, who is a rice farmer and seamstress in a garment factory.  She is asking for a loan from AMK to buy fertilizer, pesticide and to pay for laborers to plow her field.  Chrin is able to earn a small income to improve her family.

loans.use: Buy fertilizer, pesticide and to pay for laborer to plow her farm.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
The Kiva borrower is a 39-year-old single man living in Lebanon. He has twelve years of experience working as a farmer. He has owned his own farm since 2000. He works independently on his farm and he lives on his own. He cultivates only vegetables and delivers his products to the locA. agriculture markets. Today, he is asking for a loan of $1,200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to invest in supplies for his work.

With the loan, he will be able to purchase needed supplies such as seeds and fertilizers. In the future, he is planning to enlarge his land and start cultivating fruits.

loans.use: To purchase needed supplies such as seeds and fertilizers.

loans.name: Vat's Group

texts.en:
Vat R., 24, and married was selected village bank president by its nine members.  They live in Svay Prey village, Kandal province.  Each member will use their portion of the loan for different purposes.
  
Vat earns a living by breeding pigs at home while her husband is a driver.  In order to increase their income, to improve their family's living conditions, Vat decided to ask for a loan to buy more piglets for breeding and pig food.  The couple has two children who are under age six.

loans.use: Buy more piglets for breeding and pig food.

loans.name: Chan's Group

texts.en:
Four people make up this group loan.  Chan P., who is 41 year old and married, leads the group.  They all live in Khpob Veaeng village, Kandal province.  Each member will use their portion of the loan to support different businesses.
 
Chan is a Khmer noodle seller in the local market and her husband is a fisherman in the local village.  They are able to earn a small income to support their family.  In order to support her husband's business, she decided to ask for a loan to buy fishnets and to fix their boat.  They have five children.

loans.use: Buy fishnets and to fix boat.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
The Kiva borrower is a 30-year-old married man living in Lebanon. He has two young children. He is an experienced furniture carpenter. He has owned his shop for almost seven years. He works closely with some galleries in his area and also upon request of the clients. He has catalogs where the customers can choose different designs.

Today, he is requesting to borrow $1,200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase new equipment for his work. In the future, he hopes that he will be able to open his own gallery shop and presents his products.

loans.use: To purchase new equipment for his work.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret N. lives in the Mulago neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is single and has 3 children, two of whom are in school. She also takes care of additional family members (her sisters).

Margaret has a business of selling dried/smoked fish. She has been in this business for over 10 years and she works 7 days a week. Margaret sells her products at the market, by means of retail. She has requested a loan of 500,000 UGX from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy baskets of smoked fish from Gaba landing site. She also generates additional income through selling water and juice.

The main business challenge(s) for Margaret include thieves and seasonality. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to start selling by wholesale only. Margaret lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity but not to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees, medication and rent.

loans.use: To buy more baskets of fish

loans.name: Uok's Group

texts.en:
This group loan consists of four people who live in Preaek Reang village, Kandal province.  Uok P. is 65 years old and is the group's leader.  Each member of this group will use their portion of the loan for different purposes.

Uok is married with five children; two are security guards and three work as seamstresses in a garment factory.  Her husband, Eng On, 70, stays at home.

Uok supports her family by selling Khmer noodles. In order to increase her income, Uok decided to ask for a loan to buy and resell groceries.

loans.use: Buy more groceries to resell.

loans.name: Sabaly Group

texts.fr:
Les cinq membres du groupe SABALY sont des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 38 ans, 2enfants et vivant dans des  familles monogames à MANCOURANI NATIEN, un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso (3ème région administrative de la république  du Mali). 
Elles sont à leur cinquième collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle. Tous les prêts précédents ont été bien remboursés. Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce du vestimentaire et de l’alimentaire tels que les oignons avec KADIATOU D., qui compte acheter avec son  prêt,  8 sacs de 100kg d’oignon.
Elle s’approvisionne au grand marché de Médine et dans les villages avoisinants de la ville de Sikasso. Elle les revend au  grand marché de Sikasso ville et en famille  en détail, à une clientèle composée essentiellement de femmes, au comptant et souvent à crédit. 
 Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 27.500 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée  dans les dépenses de la famille et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The five members of the group called Sabaly are married women; on average, they are 38 years old and have two children each. The live in monogamous families in Mancourani Natien, one of the neighborhoods of the city of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). In order to satisfy the needs of their clientele, this is their fifth collaboration with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso. All of their previous loans have been fully reimbursed. This group of women have businesses selling clothes and food, such as onions. For example, Kadiatou Diabete intends to purchase eight 100 kilogram sacks of onions with her loan. She will purchase her supplies in the large market of Médine and in the towns neighboring the city of Sikasso. She will resell the goods in the large market of Sikasso and from her home at retail prices, for cash and often for credit. Her clientele is composed mostly of women. She hopes to earn an average monthly income of 27.500 FCFA, one part of which she will use for her family's expenses and the rest she will re-invest in her business.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase onions.

loans.name: Nget

texts.en: Nget Y., born in 1965, lives in Mea Neak village, Takeo province.  She and her husband farm and own a two-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice.  They sell the rice to support their family and their farm workers.  Her problem is that she does not have enough rice seeds to plant.  So, to improve production, Nget is seeking a loan to buy rice seeds.  She is a mother of four children; two are laborers, one is a farmer and the other attends school. Her husband is in the photo with Nget.

loans.use: Buy rice seed to grow.

loans.name: Guljan's Group

texts.en:
Guljan U. is 40; she is the leader of the group. Her spouse is a power engineering specialist in glass-works. Together, the couple is bringing up two children; the eldest works as a taxi-driver, the younger one goes to school. Over the course of five years, Guljan has started and continued her own business. She sells vegetables and fruits in the market “Bulak”. Out of profits, she helped to buy a car for her son. Guljan and her husband also breed livestock. With money received from the loan, they want to purchase sheep for breeding. In the future, she wants to obtain a computer.

Burulkan K., 39, is divorced. She has to bring up two children by herself, both of them are school students. As an unwed mother following her neighbor’s advice, she supports her family by selling fruits and vegetables in the market “Bulak”. Her earnngs have given her the possibility to obtain furniture. The loan purpose is to buy livestock animals (sheep). In the future, Burulkan is planning to make house repairs.

Akylai A. is the treasurer of the group. She is 27 and divorced. She has two small children (10 and 3 years old). The young mother has to raise money by working as a junior operator in a petrol station “Gazprom”. Out of her salary, she has managed to put some money aside in order to open her own small shop. For this aim to be achieved, she also needs a loan. In the future, Akylai wants to obtain cattle and to further increase her stock.

Asel K., 28, is married. Together with her spouse, who has a profession of a farmer, she is bringing up three children (all of them are schoolboys). Over the course of two years, the couple has been cultivated sunflower seeds and bred cattle. They want to get a loan in order to purchase more cattle for further fattening and resale. In the future, the family is planning to do house repairs.

Where Did This Loan Come From?

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan.

MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase sheep

loans.name: Real's Group

texts.en:
Four people make up this group loan.  They all live in Preak Toch village, Kandal province.  Real T. is 49 years old and the group's leader.  Each member will use their portion of the loan to support different small businesses.
 
Real decided to ask for a loan to sell cooked rice and fast food.  With a new business, Real hopes to increase her income.  She is a widow with three children: two are laborers and the other attends school.

loans.use: Sell cooked rice and fast food.

loans.name: Begaiym

texts.en:
Begaiym U. is the leader of the group; she is 38. She is a citizen of Kyrgyz Republic and lives in Kant city. She, together with her spouse, is raising three sons; two of them are schoolboys and the youngest one lives with the grandparents. Seven years ago, family friends had left for Russia to earn additionally money, while departing they had left some part of their business. Since then, Begaiym, together with her husband, run their own businesses: they sell different sorts of fish in the local market. Her husband works as smoked fish supplier round the region Yssyk-Ata, and she herself makes money additionally by working as a nurse in Tuz village. The average profit comes to 15,000 soms per month. Out of total earnings they had a possibility to make house repairs, to obtain a car, household appliances, and to give education to their children.

The family intends to obtain several kilograms of smoked and fresh fish for resale. For this purpose, they want to get a loan. For the rest money, they are planning to purchase necessary household appliances. In the future, the couple wants to give birth to a daughter, to give a good upbringing to their sons and to at last obtain a house. 

Where Did This Loan Come From?

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 

MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase fish

loans.name: Rob's Group

texts.en:
Rob S. is a 30-year-old married woman and is the leader of a group loan, having been selected by its four members, who live in Kampong Pou village, Kandal province. The members of this group will each use their portion of the loan to support their different purposes. 

 Rob S. is a grocery and vegetable seller in the local market, and she is able to earn a small income to support the family. Her husband, Mr. Phan S., who is 32 years old, earns his living with a motorbike and Khmer trailer in the local village. Since the grocery business is going well, Rob S. wants to expand it, so she decided to ask for a loan to buy more groceries to sell. This couple has three children who are between 10 and 5 years old.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Berna

texts.en:
Berna N. lives in the Kasubi Nabulagala neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has 4 children, three of whom are in school. Berna has a business of selling bananas and charcoal. She has been in this business for 9 years and she works 7 days a week.

Berna sells her products at the market by means of retail. Berna has requested a loan of 500,000 UGX from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy bags of charcoal and bunches of bananas. The main business challenge for Berna include thieves and seasonality. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to start selling by wholesale only. Berna lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees, medication and rent.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal and bunhces of bananas

loans.name: Gulnara's Group

texts.en:
Gulnara B. is the leader of the group, she is 22 and married. Her husband is a farmer. 4 years ago she used to raise money by selling foodstuff, and then she changed her business and began to sell glass-ware. Gulnara’s brother helps her run this business. Now they have managed to purchase a lot (size-four hundred parts). The loan's purpose is to buy more glass-ware for further resale. In the future she is planning to give birth to a child, to obtain a stall in the “Dordoi” market, and to support her parents materially.

Gulgaky J., 31 is  married. Together with her spouse, who is a construction worker they bring up three children (the son, a schoolboy and 2 daughters). The family began their own business 3 years ago At first they have used to breed cattle, then they built a shop next to their house and started to sell foodstuff. During these years they have managed to purchase a pavilion. The loan purpose is to increase commodity circulation. In the future the family is planning to build a house, again to do farm animal husbandry, to obtain a car and a flat.

Aisha O., 51is married. Together with her husband, who is recovering his health after an operation, they have two children (a son and a daughter). The son supports his parents by working as a builder. Today Aisha keeps house, but she wants to start her own business by selling foodstuff. For this reason she needs a loan. In the future she is planning to buy a flat, to plant trees and to build a temporary construction. 

Orolkan S. is the treasurer of the group. She is 42 and married to a man whose profession is a cattle-farm worker. The couple have five children, almost all of them are school pupils. Two years ago the clients had bought 3 farm animals, one of them was resold, then they bought 10 more livestock animals, 2 calves and had managed to earn 2000 soms. Today this business is making profit to the family. During this time they have purchased a temporary house. The loan purpose is to buy 3 livestock animals. In the future the family wants to obtain a bus, to build a big house, and give education to their children.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to buy more glass-ware

loans.name: So's Group

texts.en:
Nine people make up this village bank loan; they live in Kampong Pou village, Kandal province. Mrs. So P., 49 and married, is the village bank president having been selected by the members of this village bank loan. The members of this village loan hope to increase their income so as to better support their families in the future.   

Mrs. So P. earns her living by selling groceries. With this business, she still earns only a little income to improve the family's living conditions. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to buy more groceries to enlarge her business activity. Her husband, Mr. Saem Phall, 48 years old, works as a laborer, receiving a small salary to support his family. This couple has six children: three are laborers while the others are students and also help in their mother's business.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to enlarge her business

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 28-year-old married man with one child, who is attending school. He is the main income provider for his family and has ten years of experience working as a farmer. He has been running his own farm independently since 2003.

His specialization is using plastic tents to grow his products. These tents allow him to better monitor product quality as well as grow his products for more months during the year. 

Today, he is requesting a loan of $1200 to purchase an agricultural plow to cultivate his land.

loans.use: To purchase an agricultural plow

loans.name: Aleksandr

texts.en:
Aleksandr R. is 36 years old and lives with his family in Kant city in Kyrgyzstan. His wife earns money by working as a charwoman in the Almaluu school. The couple has three children, the daughter already a schoolgirl, the others at home. 

Fifteen years ago his wife’s parents presented them with a calf as a wedding gift. Since then the family has been breeding cattle.  Aleksandr also gets extra money by selling 7-8 liters of milk daily. Out of profits from their regularly increasing cattle stock, the family has managed to obtain a house and necessary household appliances. The total sum of profits is around $46 per month.

The family needs additional money for purchasing a cow and fattening it. For this purpose Aleksamdr wants to take out a loan. In the future he is planning to increase his cattle stock up to five cows.     

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase a cow

loans.name: Tep's Group

texts.en:
This group loan consists of five people who live in Kampong Pou village, Kandal province. Mrs. Tep Pich, born in 1962 and married, is the group leader who was selected by all the members. The members of this group will each use their portion of the loan to support their different purposes. 
 
Mrs. Tep Pich and her husband, Mr. Nou Nim, are fishermen who are able to earn a small income by selling fish to support the family. She will use the loan from AMK to buy fishing supplies. This couple has five children: Three are laborers and another is a fisherman while the fifth is a student in the local school.

loans.use: To buy fishing supplies

loans.name: Kenjegul

texts.en:
Kenjegul A. is 39 years old and she lives in Kant with her family, which consists of her husband and their two daughters. All of the family members raise money in different ways. The total sum of family income is $650 per month. Kenjegul’s spouse works as a local taxi driver, and at home he repairs cars. The elder daughter is a hairdresser and the younger one is a student on a budget base at the Medical Academy. 

Six years ago the client was the owner of a small shop, and then she changed her line and began to sell industrial goods. Now she is making her money by selling men's socks and women's underwear for all ages in the central local market. Sometimes when she is not able to manage all the workload, the daughters relieve her. In this way they have managed to purchase a house, new furniture and necessary household appliances. During these years they have also been paying for their daughter’s studies. 

The family needs a loan in order to buy more goods to sell (33,000 KGS), to do automobile repairs (10,000 KGS) and the remaining 17,000 KGS for study payment. 

In the future Kenjegul wants to obtain her own stall in the central market and to buy flats for her daughters.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase goods for sale

loans.name: Nou's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Nou L.,  born in 1969, is the leader of a group loan having been selected by its four members. They live in Kampong Pou village, Kandal province. 
 
Mrs. Nou L. earns her living by selling vegetables in the local market. Her husband, Mr. Sorn Sareoun, 40 years old, works as a laborer in a garment factory where he receives a small salary to support his family. With both occupations, they still earn only a little income to support the family. Thus, Mrs. Nou L. decided to ask for a loan to buy piglets to raise and pig feed. This couple has two children, who are students in the local school and also help with their mother's business.
.

loans.use: To buy piglets to raise and pig feed

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en: Victoria N. lives in the Kamwokya Kifumbira  neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has four children, three of whom are in school. Victoria operates a beauty salon. She has been in this business for seven years, and she works seven days out of every week. She also sells her products at the market.   Victoria  has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy boxes of creams relaxers, braids and cosmetics . She also generates additional income through  poultry farming   .The main business challenge(s) for Victoria  include   tranpsortation and  thieves  .  Her goals and aspirations for her business are owning a bridal salon . Victoria  lives in a home that she rents; she has access to electricity and has access to piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include  school fees,  medication and rent  .

loans.use: To buy more boxes of cream relaxers, braids and cosmetics

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Ket

texts.en: Mr. Ket M. is an old man whose wife appears in the photograph. Ket M., age 50, owns and operates a handicraft business whose main activity is making and selling furniture. He sells beds and rattan cupboards that he and his wife produce or that he orders from other makers who live in the village. He uses his horse cart as transportation and it takes a week to sell all his products. Mr. Ket M. is taking out his first loan in order to mend his old house that breaks down frequently.

loans.use: To mend his old house that breaks down frequently.

loans.name: Khin's Group

texts.en:
Khin N. is a 39-year-old married woman and was selected as village bank president by the four members of the group loan, which is located in Svay Prey village, Kandal province. The members of this group will each use their portion of the loan to support their different purposes. 
     
Khin N. is a farmer who owns 1-hectare of land that she uses to cultivate rice on. She will use the funding from AMK to purchase fertilizer and to hire farming laborers to grow rice. Her husband, Mr. Tharng Khan, who is 39 years old, works as foreman and builder and can earn a small income to support his family. This couple has two children: one is a government worker and another is attending the local school.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and to hire farming laborers

loans.name: Nargiza

texts.en:
Nargiza S. lives with her big family in Tyup village. She is 40 years old and has the status of being the treasurer of the group. Her husband is a farmer. Together they have given birth to six children (3 sons and 3 daughters). The eldest son contributes to the family's income by working in Russia, the second son helps his parents keep house, and the rest of the children are still in school. 

In order to support such a big family, and with the initial sum of 3,000 KGS, the main family members decided three years ago to engage in cattle breeding. By working hard they have managed to increase their stock of cattle. The total sum of their monthly income is about $34. 

The family wants to realize their plan to purchase two calves for their further fattening and resale. In order to make it come true, they need a loan. In the future Nargiza wants to continue to increase their stock of cattle, give education to the children and organize her son’s wedding. 

	--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase two calves

loans.name: Vann

texts.en: Mrs. Vann R. who lives in Mea Neak village in Takeo province was born in 1961. She is a farmer who owns a five-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to sell to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Dy Ses, is a fisherman and he owns an agric machine. She is facing a problem because it is time to grow rice, but she does not have rice seeds. So, to improve her production, Mrs. Vann R. is requesting a loan to buy rice seeds. The rest of the loan she is going to use to fix her husband’s agric machine. She is a mother of five children. Two of the children are seamstresses in a garment factory, two are farmers and the other is studying in school. Her husband is shown in the photo with her.

loans.use: To buy rice seed

loans.name: Chea's Group

texts.en:
Nineteen people are included in this village bank loan. They live in Svay Prey village, Kandal province. Chea K. is a 40-year-old married woman who is the village bank president. She was selected by the members of the loan group. 

Chea K. earns her living by cultivating vegetables. She owns a 1.5-hectare piece of land that she cultivates. Her husband, Mr. Pheng Pov, works as a fisherman who is able to earn a small profit by selling fish to support the family and he also helps his wife on the farm. In order to support her husband's fishing, Chea K. decided to ask for a loan to buy fishing supplies for fishing. This couple has two children. One of the children is a farmer who helps his mother and one is a seamstress in a garment factory.

loans.use: To buy fishing supplies for fishing.

loans.name: Chynarkul

texts.en:
Chynarkul D. lives in Kyrgyzstan, in Tyup village. She is 50 years old. Unfortunately her husband passed away, so she has to support her family alone. Her children are already adults. The eldest one (30 years old) earns his livelihood by working at a building site in Cholpon-ata city. The daughter who is 27 years old is a housewife and lives in Kant city with her husband. Another daughter (24 years old) makes money by working as a seller in the market “Dordoi”. The younger son (22 years old) lives with his mother and helps her to run their family business. 

In 2008 they bought three calves for 15,000 KGS for fattening and further resale, and since then they have managed to increase their stock of cattle by three more calves. By operating this business the family earns about $33 per month. 

The family needs money to purchase two calves for fattening and resale. For this reason they want a loan. In the future Chynarkul wants to continue to increase their stock of cattle and to buy a car. 

 --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase two calves

loans.name: Khann

texts.en: Mr. Khann P. is a villager in Mea Neak village in Takeo province. He was born in 1980. He is a farmer who owns a 1.5-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to sell to support his family. He is also a fisherman. His wife, Mrs. Ny Nouv, owns a general store in the local village where she is able to earn a large profit to support her family. Although they try to work hard, they can't earn enough income. So to improve this condition, Mr. Khann P. is asking for a loan to buy a cow to breed to start a new business. The rest of the loan he will use to buy rice seed to grow this year. He is a father of three children. One of the children is a student and the others are too small to work or study. His wife is shown in the photo with him.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding to start a new business

loans.name: Mrs. Chea Koeurn Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Chea K. who is 53 years old is the village bank president. She was selected by the 20 members of the village loan, which is located in Svay Prey village, Kandal province. With the loans, the members of this village will use their portion of the loan for different purposes. 

Chea K. is a Khmer cake seller in the local market and she is able to earn a small income to support her family. In order to increase her income to improve the family conditions, she will use the AMK loan to buy pig food and piglets to raise. Chea K. is a widow with a child who is a seamstress in a garment factory.

loans.use: To buy pig food and piglets to raise.

loans.name: Nget

texts.en:
In Mea Neak village in Takeo province lives Mrs. Nget S., who was born in 1978. She and her husband, Mr. Savoeun Nget, are farmers who own a 3-hectare plot of land in which to cultivate rice to sell to support their family. He is also a fisherman. 

She faces difficulty because in her field, it is time to grow rice, but she does not have rice seeds. So to improve this problem, Mrs. Nget S. is seeking a loan to buy rice seeds. With the rest of the loan, she will hire a plowing machine to plow her field. 

She is the mother of three children, one of whom is a laborer, while another one is a farmer and one is a student. Her husband is in the photo with her.

loans.use: To buy rice seeds

loans.name: Adama

texts.fr:
Monsieur Adama B. est marié à deux femmes et père huit enfants. Il est né le 31 Décembre 1972 à Zanso, un des villages de la préfecture de Kadiolo - 3eme région administrative du Mali.   Il vit  à Loulouni ville.
Il mène des activités commerciales depuis maintenant plusieurs 7ans. Expérimenté en raison des années dans le commerce, il le fait avec assez de réussite. 
Il est à sa deuxième collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. Le prêt passé a été correctement remboursé.
Il compte acheter avec son prêt, 6 colis d’articles composés de : lait,sucre, huile, thé, savons, biscuits, bonbons, café, lipton, œufs de poules etc. Il s’approvisionne dans les villages avoisinants et à Sikasso ville.
Il vend  dans son kiosque à Loulouni ville en détail, au comptant et souvent à crédit; à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Il envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 75.000FCFA qui sera utilisé en grande partie pour augmenter son fonds de commerce et l’autre partie sera utilisée dans les dépenses familiales.
Il envisage de faire de l’épargne pour se procurer d’un lot à usage d’habitation à Sikasso ville.
texts.en:
Mr Adama B. is married to two women and has eight children. He was born on the 31st of December 1972 in Zanso, a village in the Kadiolo region, the third largest administrative region of Mali. He now lives in Loulouni town. He has been involved in his business activities for over seven years. Through his years of experience he is now a successful businessman. He is on his second loan collaboration with the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance association, and his previous loan was successfully repaid. He aims to use his loan to purchase six parcels composed of several items: milk, sugar, oil, tea, soap, biscuits, sweets, coffee, Lipton, chicken eggs etc. He sources his goods in Sikasso's neighbouring villages. He sells his wares from a kiosk in Loulouni town, through cash and sometimes credit sales to a customer base made up of men and women. He aims to generate an average monthly profit of 75.000FCFA some of which will be used for increasing his business funds and the rest in order to meet her family's needs. He aims to put some money aside in order to buy a plot of land to live in Sikasso town.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of various goods

loans.name: In God We Trust Group

texts.en:
Rebecca W., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called In God We Trust. She is 43 years old, widowed, and has seven children, the youngest of whom is 11 years old. She was only able to attend school through 9th grade due to a lack of financial support. She describes herself as a kind and polite woman.

For ten years she has been selling used bags in 72nd Community outside of Monrovia, Liberia. She plans to use her 6,000 LRD portion of this 30,000 LRD group loan to buy more cartons of used bags. Her goals are to improve her business and to build a house.

loans.use: To buy more cartons of used bags

loans.name: Yaya

texts.fr:
Monsieur Yaya C. est marié à une femme et n’a pas d’enfant. Il est né à Nantanso vers 1986  dans la préfecture de Sikasso, 3eme région administrative du Mali.  Il vit à Loulouni dans une famille  traditionnelle élargie.
En plus de ses activités agricoles, (car  cultive environ 5 hectares  de vivres pendant la saison des pluies) il fait le commerce depuis 5 ans Il s’est spécialisé dans l’achat vente de tasses et ustensiles de cuisine en plastique.  Il mène son commerce avec assez de réussite compte tenu de son expérience à la matière.
Il est à sa deuxième collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso, le prêt antérieur a été correctement remboursé et souhaite maintenir cette relation afin de mieux  satisfaire ses clients. 
Il compte acheter avec son nouveau prêt, 6 dizaines de seaux, 5 douzaines de baignoires et 10 douzaines d'assiettes + des louches tous en plastique + 2 douzaines de bouilloires.
Il vend en détail et au comptant à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes .  
Il envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 50.000 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour augmenter le fonds de commerce et l’autre partie sera mise en épargne car il  ambitionne construire une maison à usage d’habitation à Loulouni ville.
texts.en:
Mr Yaya C. is married with no children. He was born in Nantanso in 1986 in the Sikasso region, the third largest administrative region of Mali. He lives in Loulouni in an extended traditional family. In addition to his agricultural activities (he cultivates around 5 hectars of land during the rainy season) he has been involved in business activities for five years. He specializes in the sale of cups and plastic cooking utensils. He runs his business fairly successfully given his experience. He is on his second collaboration with Soro Yiriwaso, his previous loan was successfully repaid and aims to maintain this relationship in order to better meet his customers' demands. He aims to use this loan to purchase six dozen buckets, 5 dozen bathtubs and ten dozen plates and plastic ladles, plus two dozen kettles. He sells through retail and cash sales to a customer base made up of men and women. He aims to generate an average monthly profit of 50.000 FCFA, some of which will be used to increase business funds and the rest put aside to save in order to build a house to live in, situated in the town of Loulouni.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing plastic goods

loans.name: La Victoire Group

texts.fr: Faida Joséphine  est  présidente  groupe la victoire, âgée de 48 ans, mariée, mère de 8 enfants, son mari est  chômeur. Son fils ainé a 26 ans et le cadet a 8 ans et tous étudient.  Il y a 26 ans qu’elle exerce le petit commerce de vente de la bière  Primus et Fanta. Elle a commence avec ses fonds propre reçu de son père environ 50$. Elle expose ses marchandises à son  domicile et parfois sur la rue publique. Ce crédit va lui permettre d’augmenter  son chiffre d’affaire en achetant  une parcelle de 1100$ en y associant ses épargnes  cumulatives de cycle. Le grand obstacle est  qu’elle vend en monnaie nationale (franc congolais). Cependant cette monnaie congolaise n’est pas stable, elle subit de plus à plus l’inflation, ce qui entraine de perte de change avec la devise (les dollars), comme tous les congolais craignent le franc congolais, pour garder leurs économies en dollars. Elle souhaite voir  ses enfants finir les études et doubler ses caisses de Primus et Fanta  de 40 à 70 caisses. La cliente Faida Joséphine remercie  Hekima pour  ses actions en faveur de pauvres citoyens exclus de banque classique.  Il sied de signaler que ce groupe la victoire est composé de 13 membres.
texts.en:
Faida Joséphine is the president of the La Victoire group, is 48 years old and a married mother of eight whose husband is unemployed. Her eldest son is 26 and the youngest is 8 years old; all her children are in education. She began selling Primus beer and Fanta 26 years ago. She began the business with funds that she received from her father, around 50$. She showcases her wares from her home and sometimes on the road. This loan will enable her to boost her revenues by purchasing a 1100$ plot of land through cumulative loans. The main obstacle is that she sells her goods in local currency (Congolese franc). However this currency is not stable and is subject to high inflation and often loses value against the dollar; all Congolese merchants fear the franc and keep their transactions in dollars. She would like to see her children finish school and double her stock of Primus and Fanta from 40 to 70 cases. Faida Joséphine would like to thank Hekima for its actions that help poor citizens who are excluded from the mainstream banking system. The La Victoire group is made up of thirteen members.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: A 1100$ plot of land

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: In God We Trust Group

texts.en:
Mama K., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called In God We Trust. She is 53 years old, widowed, and has three children who are between the ages of 18 to 28 years. She was only able to attend school through 7th grade due to a lack of financial support. She describes herself as a faithful woman.

For two years she has been selling lappas (a traditional dress for women) in Redlight Market outside of Monrovia, Liberia. She plans to use her 6,000 LRD portion of this 30,000 LRD group loan to buy more cartons of lappa. Her dream is to improve her business and to build a house.

loans.use: To buy more cartons of lappa

loans.name: Success Group

texts.en:
Kebbeh S., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called Success.  She is 47 years old, married, and has four children between the ages of 30 and 17 years. She was only able to attend school through 6th grade due to financial difficulties.

For thirteen years, she has been selling bitter balls (a frequent vegetable ingredient in Liberian recipes, a variety of eggplant, also known as "jilo" or "garden eggs") and dried okra in Redlight Market on the outskirts of Monrovia, Liberia. She plans to use her 16,000 LRD portion of this 76,000 LRD group loan to buy more bags of dried okra and bitter balls.
 
She describes herself as a very hard-working woman whose dream is to improve her business and build a house.

loans.use: To buy more bags of dried okra and bitter balls

loans.name: Day Break Mouth Open Group

texts.en:
Mary M., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called Day Break Mouth Open. She is 34 years old, is married, and has four children between the ages of 4 and 18 years, all of whom are in school. She also cares for two siblings. She was only able to attend school through 12th grade due to financial difficulties.

For ten years, Mary has been selling biscuits, sardines, milk, butter, sugar, soap, etc., in Duport Road Market on the outskirts of Monrovia, Liberia. She plans to use her 18,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 76,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more cartons of biscuits, sardines, milk, butter, sugar, soap, etc.

Mary describes herself as a God-fearing woman whose dream is to improve her business.

loans.use: To buy more cartons of biscuits, sardines, milk, butter, sugar, soap, etc., to sell

loans.name: Shaidullo

texts.en: K. Shaidullo is 50 years old, is married, and is the father of seven children. He is a hard-working man who has fought to provide for his family and educate his children, who today are working adults, thanks to his example. Shaidullo is an enterprising man who constantly tries to do things better and to improve, day after day. He works hard in his fields where he spends as much time as possible providing the necessary care, fertilizing his land and spraying to prevent diseases that might affect his yield. Shaidullo needs seeds and fertilizers to continue his difficult work, tending his crops so that they can be taken to the capital for sale. That's why he's applying for a loan of 6,000 Somoni. Let's be the ones who reach out our hands to help Shaidullo. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium B.C. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj.

loans.use: To purchase mineral fertilizer, fuels and lubricants

loans.name: God’S Blessing Group

texts.en:
Eyeah G., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called God’s Blessing. She is 55 years old and is married with five children between the ages of 15 and 33 years. She was not able to attend school due to financial difficulties.

For 25 years, Eyeah has been selling rice, biscuits, soap, liquor, etc., in Red Light Market outside of Monrovia, Liberia. She plans to use her 10,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 43,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more rice, biscuits, soap, liquor, etc.

Eyeah describes herself as a determined woman whose goal is to build a house.

loans.use: To buy more rice, biscuits, soap, liquor, etc., to sell

loans.name: Parda

texts.en: A. Parda is 55 years old and is married with eight children. His wife works as a teacher in the local school. For many years, Parda has lived very happily in his small house surrounded by his plantation and the "Good Morning" of a beautiful sunrise every day. He rises before sunrise and, with love and hope, he works the field that generates his family's income. Parda is applying for a loan of 4,500 Somoni with which to buy the supplies necessary for the maintenance of his crop, including seeds and fertilizer. These supplies will guarantee the quality of the harvest to which he has dedicated many hours of work during many months. loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more cartons of fish and frozen meat, bags of rice, beans, pepper, salt and seasoning

loans.name: Shernazar

texts.en: A. Shernazar is 24 years old and is married. Ever since he was young, he has been raising animals with the support of his friendly family. At the time of our visit to his business, Shernazar was absent and that’s why his mother is pictured instead. Shernazar raises cattle and, little by little over time, he has been improving and expanding his business with the goal of improving his family’s standard of living. IMON International has been a fundamental part of Shernazar’s business for the fact of having provided loans which have been used to purchase calves. Today, once again, Shernazar faces this need, and he trusts that his loan will be granted so that he can help his business and his family. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj.

loans.use: To purchase more calves to raise in order to expand his business

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary M. M. is twenty-three years old and single. She has two children aged six years and two years.

Mary’s business is located at a busy estate in Nairobi called Pumwani where she sells such items as shawls, shoes and jewelry to the local people. She has been in this business for the last six years.

Mary says that this business is profitable and the major challenge she has is the fact that there so many other people in the area doing the same kind of business as hers and so customers are spoilt for choice. However, she works hard from early morning to late evening to ensure that her business is doing well.

Mary is using her loan of Kes 20,000 to buy clothes and flower vases to meet the demand of her customers. She hopes to grow her business to a boutique in the next five years. She describes herself as hardworking and determined.

loans.use: To buy clothes and flower vases to sell

loans.name: Shermat

texts.en: H. Shermat is a hard-working man who is in agriculture. He has worked at this business for a long time and acquired his abilities in ranching and farming when he was very young. He is a married father with responsibilities for supporting his three children. Shermat is known as being very responsible and hard-working since, every day, very early in the morning, he starts his job taking care of his fields while at the same time raising cattle in his own pen located at his house. IMON International has been the backbone of Shermat’s business because of having granted loans which have allowed him to improve his standard of living through the acquisition of cattle and vegetables for planting. Today, once again, Shermat trusts that his credit will be approved so that he will be able to improve his business with the purchase of cattle and also farm supplies. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium B.C. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, fertilizer and cattle in order to expand his business

loans.name: Ulmasoy

texts.en:
M. Ulmasoy is 40 years old, widowed and has three children. The difficult circumstances and hardships in her life made her recognize the value of work from a very young age. For about seven years she has been buying young sheep and calves in the local market, fattening and selling them. Ulmasoy is a very hardworking woman, and her diligence is incredible. She works with strength worthy of immense admiration. She has always looked for a way to be an important protagonist by providing extra income in her home. Ulmasoy wakes up early every morning to feed her cows and bulls, with the goal of fattening them and selling them at the best price in the local market. She started this occupation because of the recommendation and teaching of her beloved mother. Thanks to this activity she is helping to provide her children with an education. Ulmasoy wants to keep educating them because she hopes that they’ll reach the goals that they have laid out for themselves. For this purpose, she is requesting a loan of 6,000 TJS to buy calves in order to expand her business.

More about Tajikistan
Tajikistan, a key post on the Silk Road, is perhaps best known for its rich history. It was the location for the end of Alexander the Great's rule, and is known for its great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets such as Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country, with its epic mountain passes, is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language and a civilization that dates back to the fourth millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mix of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

However, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the USSR, damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93 per cent of the country is mountainous and only 7 per cent of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands of people to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

More about IMON International
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase small cattle

loans.name: Isaac

texts.en:
Isaac B. is 33 years of age, married to Mercy Komen, and they have been blessed with five children Jepkorir 12 years old, Kibet 10 years old, Kipruto eight years old, Jelagat six years old, and Gideon five years old. B. has been in the butchery business for the past two years and he gets a monthly profit of Kshs. 3,000.

Isaac is borrowing a loan of Kshs 15,000, his first loan with KADET LTD. He intends to use Kshs. 9,000 to buy five goats, two sheep for Kshs 3,000, and 10 hens for Kshs 3,000.

In case he get profit from this loan, Isaac anticipates expanding the business and also saving some money for the education of his children. Isaac dreams and hopes to expand his business and have enough income to support his family.

loans.use: Will be used to purchase livestock for slaughter

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy boubou, fabric, and Holland wax

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more cartons of fish

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more door locks, knives, cutlasses, hinges, nails, etc.

loans.name: Emily  Chepkorir

texts.en:
Emily is aged twenty-eight and is married to Mr. Alfred aged thirty-two and both have been blessed with one child. She has been in the business for the last three years and she has been making good profit from it. Her store is situated at a very strategic place and she has a good number of customers.

She learned about KADET LTD through an existing client and with this first loan, she intends to buy additional stock, i.e., cooking oil, flour, rice and other household goods. She says that these are the products that are in high demand. Her future plan is to own a big store and open other outlets and employ more workers.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock for her general store.

loans.name: Faith

texts.en:
Faith K. K. is twenty-four years old and single. She has two children, aged six and two, whom she hopes to educate well up to the university level. Her business is located at a busy estate in Nairobi called Pumwani. She sells cereals like rice to the local people. She has been in this business for the last four years. 

She says that this business is profitable and the major challenge she has is the fact that there so many other people in the area doing the same kind of business as hers and so customers are spoilt for choice. However, she works hard from early morning to late evening to ensure that her business is doing well.

 She is using her loan of Kes 20,000 to buy more rice to meet the demand of her customers. She hopes to grow her business to a big cereals supplier. She describes herself as hardworking and determined.

loans.use: Rice

loans.name: Muhammadjon

texts.en:
M. Muhammadjon is a young and energetic guy who raises calves in a small village in Ganchi district of Sugd region. Muhammadjon is young but full of energy; he tries every single day to make the life of his family better. He started his business 4 years ago. He continued the business of his father, who is a pensioner. 

Muhammadjon has great experience in cattle breeding and the farming business because he observed it from his childhood. Muhammadjon would like to expand his business and that is the reason that he has asked for a loan. This will help him to increase his income and improve living conditions. We wish him good luck and appreciate your help!

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia.
