HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional plastics and other recyclables to sell

location.town: Villa Verde, Balulang, Cagayan De Oro, Misamis Ori

loans.name: Nhaom

texts.en: Mrs. Nhaom S. is a villager in Srae Kaes village in Takeo province and she was born in 1950. She owns a general store in the local village where she is able to earn a large profit to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Chen Sok, is a farmer who owns a 1.5-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to sell to support his family. Her problem is that her husband’s field is ready to grow rice, but she does not have money to support it. So, to improve this situation, Mrs. Nhaom S. is applying for a loan to buy rice seed. With the rest of the loan, she will buy pesticide and hire a machine to plow the rice field. She is the mother of a child who is a seamstress in a garment factory. Her husband is shown in the photo with her.

loans.use: To buy rice seed

loans.name: Or

texts.en: Mrs. Or H. is a local farmer who owns a plot of farmland where she plants various crops to earn a living. This normally generates a formal income to manage her family's daily expenses. To help her with the hard labor required, Or H. also receives help in growing crops from her husband. Or H. has five children, two are married and the others are single. Three of her children are employed and provide a small income for the family. As Or H.’s crops are not growing well due to lack of fertilizer, she is taking out a loan to purchase fertilizers to improve her crop yields.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers to improve her crop yields

loans.name: Asuncion

texts.en:
Asuncion C. is from the village of San Miguel, Manolo Fortich, Bukidnon. She is 35 years old, widowed and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Asuncion owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Asuncion has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2010, Asuncion joined Kiva partner, HSPFI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This loan was used to invest in expanding the business. Asuncion is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her second from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Choem

texts.en: Mrs. Choem V. lives in Srae Kaes village in Takeo province and she was born in 1954. She and her husband, Mr. Kim Leng Nhorn, are farmers who own a 2.5-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice on to sell to support their family. She is also a farm laborer while her husband owns a pump. Her problem is that her field is far away from the irrigation system. So, to improve her rice production, Mrs. Choem V. is seeking a loan to buy gasoline. She is a mother of four children who are all are students in a local school. Her husband is in the photo with her.

loans.use: To buy gasoline

loans.name: Margarita Del Rocío

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal María Auxiliadora se reúne en La parroquia Sequita, pertenece a Montecristi prospero cantón manabita, lleno de gente trabajadora dedicada y orgullosa de sus raíces.

Hace varios años la señora Margarita es socia del Banco Comunal y le ha gustado porque gracias a la Fundación Espoir ha logrado salir adelante en su negocio y en su vida personal. Tiene 29 años y está casada hace 10 años, fruto de esta relación tuvo 2 hijos de 4 y 2 años que son el amor de su vida, en la actualidad está en su sexto mes de embarazo de su tercer hijo, su esposo trabaja en una fábrica de atún en Manta.

Vende ropa de todo tipo y bisutería, trabaja los viernes, sábados y domingos desde las 7am hasta las 12pm en estos días aprovecha que su mama cuida a sus pequeños hijos. Compra la mercadería en Picoaza ya que allá le dan a buen precio.

Este crédito lo va a emplear en comprar más mercadería, ya que por su embarazo no se podrá movilizar y quiere comprar bastante para tener suficientes productos para no perder su clientela.
 
Sus sueños son tener un bazar y que su hijo nazca sano.
texts.en:
The María Auxiliadora Communal Bank meets in Sequita parrish, which is part of Montecristi, a prosperous canton in the province of Manabiti. For the past several years Margarita has been a member of this communal bank and she likes it because, thanks to Fundación Espoir, she has managed to get ahead in both her business and her personal life. She is 29 years old and has been married for 10 years. Two children, 4 and 2, are the result of this relationship and they are the love of her life. She is currently in the sixth month of a pregnancy with her third child. Her husband works in a tuna factory in Manta. She sells all kinds of clothing and jewelry and works Fridays, Saturdays and Sundays from 7am until noon. Those are the days she can have her mother take care of her small children. She buys the merchandise in Picoaza because she can they give her a good price there. This loan will be used to buy more merchandise since, due to her pregnancy, she cannot move around and she wants to buy plenty to have enough products to keep her customers. Her dreams are to have a shop and that her child is born healthy.

Translated from Spanish by Molly Puglisi, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy clothing and jewelry to resell.

loans.name: Medelyn

texts.en:
Medelyn V. is from the village of Barangay 5, Talakag, Bukidnon. She is 28 years old, married and has three infant-aged children. To make a living, Medelyn owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Medelyn has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 5,000 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2010, Medelyn joined Kiva partner, HSPFI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Medelyn is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her second from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Hem's Group

texts.en:
Mr. Hem H., 66, is the village bank president, having been selected by the members of this village bank loan, located in Tboung Kdei village, Kandal province. Each member of this village loan will use their portion of the loan to support their different businesses. 

Hem H. is a wedding chef and also owns a wedding hall to rent out. From the two occupations, he is able to earn a small income to support his family. For the wedding hall, he decided to ask for a loan to buy more chairs, tables and supplies to support his business. Hem H. is a widower with five children, who are students and also help with their father's businesses.

loans.use: To buy more chairs, tables and wedding hall supplies

loans.name: Ngoem

texts.en: Mrs. Ngoem N. who was born in 1956 lives in Pou Ta Mok village in Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Tum Nak, are farmers who own a 2-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice on to sell to support their family. Her husband is also a horse cart driver. This couple tries to work hard but they can earn very little money to support their family. So, to remedy this condition, Mrs. Ngoem N. is applying for a loan to buy piglets and pig feed to start a new business. With the rest of the loan she will buy fertilizer. She is a mother of four children, one of whom is a seamstress in a garment factory, while another one is a farmer, and the others are students in the local school. Her husband is in the photo with her.

loans.use: To buy piglets and pig feed and with any remainder of the loan, fertilizer

loans.name: Elena Nelly

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal María Auxiliadora se reúne en La parroquia Sequita, pertenece a Montecristi prospero cantón manabita, lleno de gente trabajadora dedicada y orgullosa de sus raíces, La Sequita es una parroquia donde sus habitantes son gente honesta que solo saben trabajar y dedicarse a sus familias.

La señora Elena es socia fundadora del Banco Comunal y siempre le han gustado las reuniones ya que en ellas se divierte con sus amigas y aprende cosas nuevas. Mantiene una relación de unión libre y tiene 7 hijos todos mayores de edad, tres de ellos viven con ella los mismos que junto a su esposo trabajan en el campo.

Tiene una pequeña granja de pollos en su casa, compra por cajas los pollos cuando están pequeños, los cría por tres meses y luego los vende en pie o por libras a los vecinos o entrega a las tiendas de la localidad, dice que sus pollos se venden mucho ya que los cría con maíz por lo cual su carne es  parecida al pollo criollo. Trabaja todos los días dos a tres horas por día.

Este crédito lo va a emplear en comprar más pollos porque la temporada que se avecina es muy buena y quiere tener bastante.

Su sueño es tener una granja grande y con tecnología.
texts.en:
The María Auxiliadora Communal Bank meets in Sequita parrish, which belongs to Montecristi, a properous canton in the province of Manabí. The area is filled with hardworking people who are proud of their roots. Sequita is a parrish whose residents are honest people who only know how to work and take care of their families. Elena is a founding member of the communal bank and has always liked the meetings because they have fun with friends and learn new things there. She is in a common-law marriage and has 7 children, all adults. Three live with her and work with her husband in the fields. She has a small chicken farm at her home. She buys the young chicks by the box, raised them for three months and then sells them individually or by the pound to neighbors or delivers them to local shops. She says she sells a lot of chickens because she raises them on corn and so their meat is similar to pen-raised chickens. She works every day for two to three hours per day. This loan will be used to buy more chickens because the upcoming season is very good and she wants to have enough. Her dream is to have a large farm which uses technology.

Translated from Spanish by Molly Puglisi, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy chickens.

loans.name: Choeun's Group

texts.en:
Four people make up a group loan located in Kampong Samnanh village, Kandal province. Mrs. Choeun B. who is 69 years old is the village bank president, having been selected by the members of this group loan. 

Choeun B. earns her living by renting out her house to someone for income. Her house is old and somewhat broken down. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to fix her house up. Choeun B. is a widow with five children: three are seamstresses in a garment factory and another is an electrician while the last one is a student in the local school.

loans.use: To fix her house up (she rents it out)

loans.name: Mila

texts.en:
Mila M. is from the village of Barangay 5, Talakag, Bukidnon. She is 48 years old, married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Mila owns and operates a business venture in the food sector making and selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. Mila has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2010, Mila joined Kiva partner, HSPFI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This loan was used to purchase additional ingredients and as working capital. Mila is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be her second from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Moeurng

texts.en: Mrs. Moeurng S. has been operating a farming business for years. She owns a piece of land where she raises pigs and crops. From these activities, she is able to earn a stable income to meet her family's financial crisis. Moeurng S. is a single mother who is devoted to her five children: three are married and two are single. Most of her children are working in different jobs. There is a piece of land for sale currently owned by a village. It is in a good location for business and home. Moeurng S. wants to own this piece of land, but her savings are insufficient to buy it. That is why she has decided to apply for a loan in order to buy the land. She hopes to build a small house for her married children to live in and breed a few animals for additional revenue.

loans.use: To buy a piece of land

loans.name: Sem

texts.en: Mrs. Sem P. was born in 1966 and she lives in Pongro village in Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Roeun Pheng, are farmers who own a 1-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice on to sell to support their family. Her husband is also a farm laborer. Her problem is that her field has infertile soil, but she does not have enough money to amend it. So, to improve her rice production, Mrs. Sem P. is seeking a loan to buy fertilizer and pesticide. With any remainder of the loan, she will hire someone to plow her field. She is a mother of three children, two of whom are attending school, while the youngest one is three years old. Her husband is in the photo with her.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and pesticide and hire someone to plow

loans.name: Pech's Group

texts.en:
This group loan consists of four people located in Thmei village in Kandal province. Mrs. Pech T., 38 and married, is the group leader having been selected by the members of this group. Each member of this group will use their portion of the loan to support their different purposes.
 
Pech T. and her husband, Mr. Sorn Theoun, are fishermen who are able to earn a small income to support their family. They lack some money to support their fishing business, so Pech T. decided to ask for a loan to buy fishnet and fishing supplies. This couple has two children who are attending the local school.

loans.use: To buy fishnet and fishing supplies

loans.name: Rosefe

texts.en:
Rosefe E. is from the village of San Simon, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 41 years old, is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Rosefe raises pigs for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Rosefe joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosefe has successfully repaid a previous loan of 16000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in the future. She is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional animals. This loan will be the 6th loan taken out by Rosefe from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional animals

location.town: San Simon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Oscar

texts.en:
Oscar P. J. is from the village of Lactawan, Solano, Nueva Vizcaya. He is 29 years old. Oscar is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Oscar plants and harvests rice for sale. Oscar has been engaged in his business for over seven years and earns approximately 45000 PHP per harvest.

In 2007, Oscar joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Oscar has successfully repaid a previous loan of 25000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. 

Oscar is requesting a new loan of 30000 PHP which will be used to pay for services to increase crop yield. This loan will be the 7th loan taken out by Oscar from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to pay for services to increase crop yield

loans.name: Sek

texts.en: Mrs. Sek L. H. lives in Roka village in Takeo province and she was born in 1955. She is a farmer who owns a 1.5-hectare plot of land where she grows rice to sell to support her family. Her problem is that her field is infertile, and she does not have enough money to amend it. So, to improve her rice production, Mrs. Sek L. H. is requesting a loan to buy fertilizer, pesticide, gasoline, and rice seed. She is a widow with two children, one of whom is a seamstress in a garment factory, while the other is a cosmetician.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, pesticide, gasoline, and rice seed

loans.name: Hak's Group

texts.en:
Nine people, who are living in Dang Kdaong village, Kandal province, make up a village bank loan. They selected Mrs. Hak S., who is 34 years old and married as the village bank president. With their loan, each member of this village bank hopes to increase his or her income to improve the living conditons of their family.

Mrs. Hak S. earns her living through her rice and corn selling. She is a farmer who owns a piece of land to cultivate rice and corn on. Her husband, Mr. Sam Sarorn, who is 36 years old, works as motorbike repairman in the local village. With both occupations, they are able to earn some income to support their family. Mrs. Hak S. will use the loan from AMK to buy motorbike spare parts to support her husband's business. This couple has two children, who are students in the local school and also support their parents' businesses.

loans.use: To buy motorbike spare parts for her husband's business

loans.name: Shalom: Dios Con Nosotros Group

texts.es: La señora Olga tiene 49 años y es la secretaria del grupo “Shalom” que significa Dios con nosotros, los 8 miembros del grupo viven en Huaycan. Olga venD. ropa junto a su pareja, por este trabajo y los ahorros que ah acumulado ha enviado a sus dos hijas a la Argentina para que puedan prosperar por su parte, por su lado ella desea poner una galería D. venta D. ropas y para esto desea que Edaprospo aumente su capacidad D. Credito.
texts.en:
Olga, age 49, is secretary of the “Shalom” group. "Shalom" means God. The eight members of the group live in Huaycan. Olga and her life partner sell clothes together. With this work and the savings they gathered they have sent their two daughters to Argentina so that they are able to prosper. Olga wishes to establish a gallery selling clothes. In order to do so she wants Edaprospo to increase her loan limit.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy products and supplies

loans.name: Genelyn

texts.en:
Genelyn G. is from the village of South Cogon, Tagoloan, Misamis Oriental. She is 34 years old. Genelyn is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Genelyn makes and sells food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling snacks & other delicacies in the local community. Genelyn has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Genelyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Genelyn is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Genelyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding her food business

loans.name: Seang's Group

texts.en:
Seang S. is a 35-year-old married woman and the village bank president, having been selected by its four members, located in Ampil Tuek village, Kandal province. 

Seang S. is a grocery seller at the local market who can earn a small income to support the family. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it, so she decided to ask for a loan to buy more groceries to enlarge her business. Her husband can earn some income working as a car mechanic. This couple is working very hard to support their five children. Two are car mechanics while the other three are attending the local school and also help their mother with her business.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to enlarge her business

loans.name: Khit's Group

texts.en:
This group loan has four members who live in Trapeang Roka village in Takeo province. Mrs. Khit S. is the group leader, born in 1948 and selected by the other members who will each use their portion of the loan for different purposes. She and her husband are farmers who own a 2-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice on to sell to support their family. Her husband also owns an agricultural machine.

 Her problem is that her field has infertile soil, but she does not have money to amend it. So, to improve rice production, Mrs. Khit S. is seeking a loan to buy fertilizer and pesticide. She is the mother of a child who is a laborer.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and pesticide

loans.name: Vorn

texts.en:
The two people in the photo above are Mrs. Vorn S. and her husband. 

Making furniture is a significant part of this couple’s daily routine. They work from home producing their items which they also sell to make a daily income. Most of their output consists of beds and cupboards, which they accumulate and sell as a set. Their furniture is made mostly from wood and rattan. 

The couple has two children, both of whom are in primary school. 

In addition to their furniture business, Vorn S. has applied for an $1,000 loan to buy a cultivating machine that she will provide as a plowing service to farmers for a fee.

loans.use: To buy a cultivating machine that she uses to provide a plowing service to farmers for a fee.

loans.name: Ma. Esperanza

texts.en:
Ma. Esperanza J. is from the village of Villa Verde, Balulang, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 45 years old and has four adult-aged children. Ma. Esperanza is separated from her spouse. To make a living, Ma. Esperanza makes & sells food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from making and selling dried fish and homemade sausage, or "longganiza," in the local community. Ma. Esperanza has been engaged in her business for over one year and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Ma. Esperanza joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ma. Esperanza has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Ma. Esperanza is requesting a new loan of 11000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Ma. Esperanza from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients needed to make food products for sale

location.town: Villa Verde, Balulang, Cagayan De Oro, Misamis Ori

loans.name: Las Violetas Group

texts.es: La señora Domitila tiene 42 años y vive en la zona de Huaycan, es conviviente y tiene 2 hijos de los cuales aun está a cargo de 1, ya lleva 3 años trabajando con Edaprospo en el grupo  “Las Violetas” el cual lo conforman 8 miembros. Domitila trabaja en su bar desde hace ya un año al cual los vecinos le han llamado “El Hueco” pues es donde se refugian del sol después de jugar al futbol, su pareja trabaja en la moto taxi que pudieron comprarse con sus ahorros  y en el futuro tiene planeado poner un restaurante en su casa, pero para eso necesita que Edaprospo haga más habilitaciones.
texts.en:
Ms. Domitila is 42 years old and lives in the Huayacan area. She is in a common-law marriage and has two children, one of whom is still in her care. She has been working with EDAPROSPO for three years, with her group, "Las Violetas" ["The Violets"], which is made up of eight members. For a year, Domitila has worked in her bar, which her neighbors have called "El Hueco" ["The Alcove"] because it is where they take refuge from the sun after playing soccer. Her partner works in the motorcycle taxi that he bought with their savings. In the future, she plans to put a restaurant in her house, but in order to do so, she will need EDAPROSPO to make more loans to her.

Translated from Spanish by Katie Kavanagh, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy products and supplies

loans.name: Norng's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Norng S. is a 56-year-old married woman and was selected as the leader of a group loan consisting of five members, located in Ta Reap Doun Sa village, Kandal province. 

Norng S. works at fishing and is able to earn a small income to support her family. She lacks money to support the business, so she decided to ask for a loan to buy a fishing boat and fishnets. Her husband, Mr. Sae Hean, is 65 years old, and works as a traditional healer and also helps his wife in the business. This couple has four children: two are seamstresses in a garment factory and one is a security guard while another is a fishermen who helps his mother with fishing.

loans.use: To buy a fishing boat and fishnets

loans.name: Carlito

texts.en: Carlito D. is from the village of Siempre Viva Norte. He is 35 years old. Carlito is married and has an infant child. To make a living, Carlito runs a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Carlito has been engaged in his business for over four years and earns approximately 3,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2008, Carlito joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Carlito has successfully repaid a previous loan of 9,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase new items to expand his product offering. Carlito is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Carlito from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. loans.name: Glaiza

texts.en:
Glaiza R., from the village of Barangay 4, Talakag, Bukidnon, is 22 years old, separated from her spouse, and has one infant-aged child. To make a living, Glaiza owns and operates a specialized retail store buying and selling a variety of dried fish in the local community. Engaged in her business for over four years, she earns approximately 7000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Glaiza joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan of 8000 PHP from HSPFI that was used to invest in expanding the business,she is now requesting a new loan of 11000 PHP to purchase additional inventory and use as working capital. This will be Glaiza's third loan from HSPFI, and she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

Ath K. and her husband, Mr. Y Vet, 54 years old, are farmers who own a plot of land that they use to cultivate vegetable for a living. In order to support this farm, Ath K. will use the loan to buy fertilizer to cultivate vegetables. Aside from being farmers, they are also fishermen who are able to earn a small income to support their family. This couple is works very hard to support their three children. The children are students who also help their parents businesses.

texts.en: Daisy A. is from the village of Tumpagon, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 35 years old. Daisy is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Daisy runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily-use products in the local community while her husband is working on their farm. Daisy is just starting this business. loans.name: Mrs. Khorn In Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Sixteen people make up this village bank loan located I. Ta Paen village I. Takeo province. They have selected Mrs. Khorn I., who was born I. 1976, as the village bank president. They will each use their portion of the loan for different purposes, I. ways that can improve their lives. 

Mrs. Khorn I. and her husband, Mr. Run Phak, are farmers who own a half-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to sell to support their family. She is also raising two pigs. Her husband is a laborer. She is the mother of three children, two of whom are students. The youngest one is six years old.

Since her pig business going well, she wants to expand. So, to improve this business, Mrs. Khorn I. is applying for a loan to buy more piglets and pig food, and rest of the loan she will use to purchase fertilizer for their field.

loans.use: To buy more piglets, pig food

loans.name: Eang

texts.en:
Mrs. Eang L. can pursue a daily income in the amount of $4 by doing farming. Eang L. is married with seven children, four of whom are married and have started their own homes, while the remaining three are single. Her husband also assists to work in the farm fields frequently alongside her. 

Growing potatoes and green beans is an annual action with which she has had great success. She is able to plant the crops at least twice a year by following both rainy and dry seasons. For the approaching farming season, Eang L. needs capital to buy fertilizer, insecticide, and seeds to cultivate on her own farmland. This is why she requested a loan from Kiva.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, insecticide, and seeds to grow on her own farmland.

loans.name: Cerila

texts.en:
Cerila L. is from the village of Tumpagon, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 46 years old, married and has seven adult-aged children. To make a living, Cerila owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Cerila has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2008, Cerila joined Kiva partner, HSPFI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 13,000 PHP from HSPFI. This loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Cerila is requesting a new loan of 16,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be her fifth from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

Fifteen people make up this village bank loan located in Slab Ta Aon village, Kandal province. Koem C. is a 52-year-old married woman and was selected as the village bank president by the members. The members of this village loan will use their portion of the loan to support their different purposes.

loans.name: Lach

texts.en:
Mrs. Lach M., age 51, owns and operates a handicraft business whose main activity is selling rattan cupboards. She sells rattan that she and her husband weave or she orders from other weavers who live in the village. This couple uses their own motorcycle with trailer attached as transportation and it takes a week to sell all their rattan. 

Lach M. currently gets a lot of orders for rattan from her customers, but her output is not enough to serve them. In order to better meet the needs of her customers, Lach M. is humbly requesting a loan to buy more rattan cupboards to resell.

loans.use: To order buy more rattan cupboards to resell

loans.name: Mrs. Chan Rein Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan, located I. Ou Kralang Duol village I. Takeo province, is made up of twenty people. They have selected Mrs. Chan R., who was born I. 1965, as the village bank president. They will each use their portion of the loan I. various ways to improve their family's standard of living.

She is the mother of three children, one of whom is a seamstress I. a garment factory, another one is a construction worker, and the third is a student. Her husband, Mr. Pheap Ngen, is a construction worker.

loans.name: Khen

texts.en:
Khen S. A., 30, is a garment factory worker in Takeo province. She is married with two children, who are still living at home, and her husband is a security guard. She typically makes about US$ 6 each day. 

Since this family spends a lot on transportation, Khen S. A. would like to take out a loan of US$ 500 to purchase a motorbike to reduce transportation costs.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike

loans.name: Ny

texts.en: Ny V., 35, lives in Takeo province and has a balloon darts business where children pay to play the fun game. She is married with three children, who are still living at home, and her husband works with her. She typically makes about US$ 2 each day and would like a loan to expand her business. In order to increase her profits, she is asking for US$ 700 to purchase more toys to give the children when they win the game.

loans.use: To purchase more toys

loans.name: Gnem

texts.en:
Gnem M., 32, is married and lives with her two young children in Takeo province. She is a farmer who works for less than US$ 1 each day, while her husband is employed as a garment factory worker making US$ 3 each day. The weather conditions have been difficult for farming in Cambodia this past year and inflation has caused food prices to skyrocket. These factors have played into a difficult economic year for many Cambodians, Gnem M. included.

 Since her family spends a lot on transportation, she needs to take out a loan to purchase a motorbike.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Teresa

texts.en:
Teresa S. is from the village of Barangay 2, Talakag, Bukidnon. She is 36 years old. Teresa is widowed and has one infant child. To make a living, Teresa owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Teresa has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Teresa joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Teresa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Teresa is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Teresa from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Mrs. Srun Koem Lieng Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan is made up of nine people, located in Chroung Sdau village in Takeo province. Mrs. Srun K. L., who was born in 1951, is the village bank president, selected by the other members. They will use their portion of the loan in different ways to improve their family's standard of living. 

Mrs. Srun K. L. is a farmer who owns a one-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to sell to support her family. She has a problem because her field has infertile soil. So, to improve production, she is using her portion of the loan to buy fertilizer and to hire a machine to plow her field. 

She is a widow and the mother of a child who is married.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Soeung

texts.en: Soeung S., 38, is married with three young children living at home in Takeo province. She raises and sells pigs, typically making US$ 1 each day; her husband works in construction. Her husband typically makes about US$ 3 each day. Soeung S. would like a loan of US$ 650 to raise more pigs.

loans.use: Raise pigs

loans.name: Chan

texts.en: Chan L., 29, is a garment factory worker in Takeo province. She is married with one child who is still living at home, and her husband has a business making cow ropes. She typically makes about US$ 3 each day. Since this family spends a lot on transportation, Chan L. would like to take out a loan of US$ 1200 to purchase a motorbike to reduce transportation costs.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike

loans.name: Estrella

texts.en:
Estrella B. is from the village of Barangay 1, Talakag, Bukidnon. She is 43 years old. Estrella is separated from her spouse and has one  very young child. To make a living, Estrella owns & operates a business venture making & selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from making and selling snacks & other delicacies like steamed rice cake with cheese in the local community. Estrella has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Estrella joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Estrella has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Estrella is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional ingredients and as working capital. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Estrella from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional ingredients and as working capital

loans.name: Cristina

texts.en:
Cristina G. is from the village of Mabasa, Dupax del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 35 years old. Cristina is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Cristina owns & operates a transportation business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from providing motorcycle transport to local community members. Cristina has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Cristina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Cristina is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to repair a transport vehicle used in the business. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Cristina from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. location.town: Mabasa Dupax del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya

loans.name: Ouk

texts.en: Ouk C. is 43 years old and sells fruit in Takeo province. Her business has been around for about nine years and she makes US$ 15 every day in revenue. She is a widow with four children; two are in school and the other two are employed. Selling fruit has been a difficult business, as there is high inflation and weather conditions have not been conducive to a good growing season. She is asking for a loan of US$ 300 to invest in her own fruit business, increasing her stock of fruit to sell.

loans.use: To invest into her own fruit business

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.en:
Yolanda L. is from the village of Sto. Niño, Talakag, Bukidnon. She is 38 years old. Yolanda is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Yolanda owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Yolanda has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Yolanda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Yolanda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Yolanda is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Yolanda from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Thon

texts.en: Thon L., 29, is married with three young children living at home in Takeo province. She makes and sells brooms at the local market, typically making US$ 1 each day and her husband works in construction. Her husband typically makes about US$ 3 each day. Thon L. would like a loan of US$ 400 to purchase a motorbike as currently this family spends a lot on transportation costs.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike

loans.name: May

texts.en:
Mrs. S. is 42 years of age and a married woman. In order to cover the needs of the family, S. built a small store in front of her house where she sells a few groceries. She has been in this sector for eighteen years and is earning approximately US$ 5 per day. To help support the family, her husband works repairing vehicles in his village. 

S. is blessed with two children who are employed: one is a painter and one sews clothes to earn a living. S. has a child who wants to buy land where she will build a new house to live separately. As she doesn’t have money yet, S. is applying for a loan for her child use to buy a piece of land.

loans.use: To buy a piece of land for her daughter

loans.name: Sok

texts.en: Sok M., 46, is a professional silk weaver, making US$ 2 each day in Takeo province. She is married and has four children living at home to support. Her husband makes approximately US$ 5 every day, selling furniture. Sok M. would like a loan of US$ 1000 to purchase more furniture for resale.

loans.use: purchase furniture to resell

loans.name: Jumanazar

texts.en:
O. Jumanazar is a hardworking man who dedicates himself to his cattle-breeding business to support his wife and five children. He is now requesting a loan to purchase pregnant cows that he will ultimately sell in order to increase his profits.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes its role as a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase cattle in order to expand the business

loans.name: Pov

texts.en: Pov K., 27, sells rice in the local market of her TaK. province. She is married with one child, who is still living at home. Her husband sells mosquito nets and blankets. She typically makes about US$5 a day and would like a loan to expand her business. In order to increase her profits, she is asking for US$1200 to purchase more rice to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more rice to sell

loans.name: Robert

texts.en:
Robert R. is from the village of Tinagaan, Salay, Misamis Oriental. He is 32 years old and single. To make a living, Robert buys and sells bananas in the local community. Robert has been engaged in this business for over two years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Robert joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Robert has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI which he used to purchase additional bananas to sell. Robert is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be his third loan from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand his business. 

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and for working capital

loans.name: Heng

texts.en: Heng S., 26, raises chickens and grows rice in the Takeo province. She is married with two children, who are still living at home. Her husband sells grilled eggs. She typically makes about 2.60 USD each day, while her husband earns 13 USD in revenue. She would like a loan to expand her husband’s business. In order to increase profits, she is asking for 400 USD to purchase more eggs for resale.

loans.use: To purchase eggs

loans.name: Chim

texts.en: Chim S., 30, is married and lives with her husband in the Takeo province. She works in a garment factory and is able to make about 3.50 USD every day. Her husband stays at home, planting and selling trees. On average, he makes 2 USD per day. Since this couple earns a small income, on which they must support their family, Chim S. would like to take out a loan of 1000 USD to purchase a motorbike for her husband to operate a moto-taxi.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike

loans.name: En

texts.en: En K., 25, is married with one young child living at home in the Takeo province. She works in the local market selling chickens, typically making 16 USD in revenue each day. Her husband operates a taxi business and typically makes about 3.50 USD each day. En K. would like a loan of 1200 USD to invest in her chicken business.

loans.use: Invest in chicken business

loans.name: Sonia

texts.en:
Sonia A., from the village of Mabasa Dupax del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya, is 42 years old, married, and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Sonia owns and operates a transportation business providing motorcycle transport to local community members. Engaged in her business for over five years, she earns approximately 4000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Sonia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Now requesting her first loan of 5000 PHP to repair a transport vehicle used in the business, she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family.

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

location.town: Mabasa Dupax del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya

texts.en: S. Omina is 40 years old and, since she lost her husband, has worked in the business of buying and selling cattle and also breeding sheep. She uses the profit to cover the family expenses and her children’s education fees. She has three children. Her first child has already graduated from school while the others are studying in school. The loan from IMON International will be used to purchase more calves to expand her business. Omina hopes that the business goes well and her family has a better quality of life. loans.name: Tim

texts.en:
Tim V., 43, is married with three children living at home in Takeo province. She is a garment factory worker, typically making US$3 each day and her husband, pictured here, is a moto-taxi driver, typically making about US$3 each day.

Tim V. would like a loan of US$1,000 to make a new investment. She wants to purchase fabric from the factory and resell it in the local market for a profit.

loans.use: To buy fabric to sell

loans.name: Toeun

texts.en:
Toeun P., 26, is married with one young child living at home in Takeo province. She is a garment factory worker, typically making US$2 each day.

Toeun P.’s husband sells brooms at the local market, typically making about US$4 each day. Toeun P. would like a loan of US$500 to buy brooms in bulk so that her husband can receive a special discount.

loans.use: To enable her husband to buy brooms in bulk

loans.name: Kosar's Group

texts.en:
Kosar is a resident of a city called Vehari, in Pakistan, a city famous for its agriculture. She owns a two-room brick house and has been living in it with her family for over fifteen years.

Kosar is a very simple and kind-hearted lady. She prefers to stay at home handling household chores and taking care of her family. She not only takes care of her family’s needs but also supports her husband financially by handling sewing work at home. She sews clothes for her neighbors on a regular basis and charges them between 100 and 150 PKRs. She sews the clothes with perfect measurements and, due to her neatly sewed dresses, her customers come to her again and again to give her orders. She utilizes her earning in paying the utilities.

Kosar’s husband’s name is M. Y. and he is involved in a business selling seeds and fertilizer. His clientele base consists of farmers and, as he lives in an agricultural city, his work is considered best for earning good money. He usually receives good orders from his customers and, due to his timely fulfillment of orders, has obtained a good reputation with them.

Kosar has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband’s business. With the loan, her husband will buy seeds and fertilizer in bulk which will enable him to maintain his reputation with his customers by fulfilling their orders on time.

In the photo, Kosar is the lady who is raising her hand.

loans.use: To enable her husband to buy seeds and fertilizer in bulk

loans.name: Sourn

texts.en:
Mr. Sourn P. is a middle-aged man whose wife is shown in the photograph. Sourn P. and his wife own a plot of farmland that they inherited from their parents. On the land, they grow various crops to earn a living.

Besides this, the couple also travels to the forest where they buy chop-wood (firewood) and transport it to sell at their home. Sourn P. sees that the chop-wood trade is a profitable one for his family and he wants to enlarge it as he hopes he will be able to improve his profit.

Therefore, Sourn P. looks for assistance from Kiva in order to buy a bigger quantity of firewood from the forest people to resell.

loans.use: To buy a bigger quantity of firewood to sell

loans.name: Nuon

texts.en: Nuon N., 23, together with his wife, makes and sells brooms at the local market in Takeo province. They have been running this business since 2005 and they are able to make US$4 profit every day. They have one young child living at home to support. Since Nuon N. spends a lot on transportation to bring brooms to the market, she would like to take out a loan of US$800 to purchase a motorbike to carry them.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Mrs. Ao Sokhon Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Ao S., born in 1969, is the village bank president, selected by fifteen members who will each use their portion of the loan for different purposes to improve their families' living conditions. They are located in Rumchek village in Takeo province. She works as a weaver at her home where she is able to earn some money to support her family. 

Since her business is going well, she wants to expand. So, Mrs. Ao S. is seeking a loan to buy more silk. Her husband, Mr. Huon Hai, is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice on to feed his family and he is also a construction worker. She is a mother of four children, one of whom is a driver, while two others are attending school, and the youngest one is only three years old.

loans.use: To buy more silk

loans.name: Marito

texts.en:
Marito T. is from the village of Sabangan, Waterfall, Balingasag, Misamis Oriental. He is 57 years old and married with two school-aged children. To make a living, Marito provides motorela or habal-habal transportation services to local community members. He is just starting this business.

In 2006, Marito joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marito has successfully repaid a previous loan of 16000 PHP from HSPFI to purchase materials needed to provide service and is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP to invest in renovating the business. This will be the 10th loan taken out by Marito from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand the his business. 

About HSPFI: HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: to invest in renovating the business

loans.name: Habiba

texts.en:
Habiba is an enterprising woman, always happy to do good work. When she was young, she had the goal of self-improvement. For about 20 years she has been breeding cattle and sheep. This allows her to support her four children who are the reason of her being; she has raised them alone since she is widow. Habiba's parents also live with them. Habiba wants to increase her capital to buy new animals so she can keep supporting the family.
