Joseph Egateli A. is a 31 years old man and married to Mary Akai Egateli. They have two children, ages 10 years, and two years respectively. They live in Mwanyaka, 1km from Eldoret town. Joseph sells charcoal, where he earn his income. He has been in this business for the past five years with an income of Kshs.6,000 per month.

Joseph was introduced to KADET LTD by a Credit officer and he is applying for his first loan of Kshs.10,000 with KADET LTD. With this loan he plans to purchase more bags of charcoal 

He hopes with the income made, to buy two motorbikes for transportation in future.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of  charcoal

loans.name: Sayorai

texts.ru: Сайёраи Шариф жительница района Варзоб. Возраст, 29 лет. Замужем, имеет 2 детей. Образование высшее, учительница. Работает по профессии. Кроме того занимается шитьем национальных платьев и подушек. В этой области более 5 лет. Целью кредита является покупка швейной машины.
texts.en:
Sayorai S. lives in the Varzob district. She is 29 years old, married and has 2 children. She has a higher education, as a teacher. She works in her field. Besides this work, Sayorai is also involved in sewing national dresses and pillows. She has been in this business for over 5 years. The goal of this loan is a purchase of a sewing machine.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of a sewing machine

loans.name: Oliver

texts.en:
Oliver N. is 22 years old and lives in the town of Kyengera in the Kampala West region of Uganda.  She is married and has 1 child.  None of her children is currently in school.  Oliver has a business of a retail shop, which she has had for 2 years.  Oliver has another business of a pay phone and selling phone air time  

To help expand her business, OOliver has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase sugar, maize flour and phone air time.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Oliver hopes to generate greater profits and help her side of family.  In the future, Oliver hopes to do business with outside countries.  Oliver is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by helping her increase on business

loans.use: to buy sugar and maize flour

loans.name: Gulomdjon

texts.en:
B. Gulomdjon is 53 years old man. He is married and has two children. Gulomdjon’s goals are to grow in his personal life and in his business. His wish is to offer better service to his customers. His dream is that God continues to provide him with more life to get ahead and to fulfill his goals. He is a taxi driver and travels the streets of Kanibadam city in search of customers. He has owned his business for 3 years. 

Today Gulomdjon is planning to buy new and better car in order to earn more money. That is the reason he wants to borrow $1500 USD. Gulomdjon sincerely thanks Kiva and all lenders that make this help possible.    


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchase a new car

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
Gina A. is a 40-year old married woman who supports her family by operating 2 business ventures:  Fish vending and clothes retailing businesses. She lives in Prk. Cordova, Brgy. Bocana, Ilog, Negros Occidental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2003 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her fish vending and clothes sales businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 30000. 

Gina is now borrowing PHP 20000 to add to her operating capital of her fish vending business. This will be her 12th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 17000, which she paid off well within its term was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Gina aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the  Dungganon way.

About NWTF: 
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Additional working capital

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Khosiyatkhon

texts.en:
K. Khosiyatkhon is 41 is years old. She is married with three children. She began her business to keep herself busy and active when she found herself sad and depressed due to her separation, as well as in order to have an independent income. That is why her business is the main source of income of her family. 

Khosiyatkhon has been running her own small business for 10 years. She rents a store in the local market for selling the candies and different kinds of sweets. She works from 8:00 a.m. till 5:00 p.m. Khosiyatkhon is very friendly and polite which has provided her with a large clientele. Now she requests a loan for 6500 Somoni. She is planning to spend the loan purchasing more goods and increasing the variety of goods. The profits will  provide for her children's needs and their school fees. Khosiyatkhon promises to repay her loan without any violation and thanks everybody who decided to support her. 


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchase goods to increase the stock

loans.name: Abdumanon

texts.ru: Сафарбеков Абдуманон проживает в районе Яван. Возраст, 54 года. Женат, имеет 3 детей. Образование среднее. Более 10 лет занимается растениеводством. При доме имеет земельный участок, где выращивает овощи и сеет пшеницу. Кредит берет для закупа семян.
texts.en:
Abdumanon S. lives in the Yavan district. He is 54 years old, married and has 3 children. He has a secondary education. Abdumanon has been involved in agriculture for over 10 years. He has a land plot at home, where he grows vegetables and sows wheat. He is requesting this loan for the purchase of seeds.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of seeds

loans.name: Janette

texts.en:
Janette G. is a married woman who lives in Purok Paho, Barangay Bocana, Ilog, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating three business ventures: a general store, fishing, and food-vending. Her husband, Nestor G., who is 47 years old, works as a fisherman to earn his living. They have four children who are from 8 to 18 years old, with their oldest child already working and helping support the education of her three brothers.

Janette joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2004 because she wished for something better for her family. With the help of her past five loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, she has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 10,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 7,000, uplifting her family's standard of living.

This time, for her 6th loan, Janette is borrowing PHP 12,000, which she intends to use to purchase more stock to sell so that she can continue to save for the future education of her children.

Janette is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.


About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

Help NWTF continue in its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by visiting the NWTF lending team on Kiva to join our team.

loans.use: To purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth S. is from the village of Siempre Viva Norte. She is 43 years old and is married with four school-aged children. Elizabeth owns and operates a business raising pigs for fattening and sale. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month. In 2008, Elizabeth joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase pig feed and other supplies. Elizabeth is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase medication for her pigs. This loan will be her 5th from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children’s tuition fees. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small-business entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase medication for her pigs

loans.name: Ddembe Gayaza Group, Mubende

texts.en:
Having ventured into the business of cattle keeping, hardworking K. Abu Baker of Ddembe Gayaza group, Mubende, has no regrets about the advice he got from friends to begin his current business that he operates from Kiganda, Mubende.

Being part of his culture commonly carried out in western Uganda where people own large heads of cattle, the 34-year-old has benefited a lot from his farming business. He deals in selling cattle; hides and beef are some of the products obtained by his customers from his farming business.

Abu Baker’s motive to acquire this loan is to help him buy sprays for his cattle to kill ticks and also de-worming medicine to treat against diseases that affect his cattle. In addition, he will purchase more cattle for fattening on his farm. This will help him increase production as well as his revenue.

In the future, Abu Baker looks at doing further restocking to have more cows on his farm.

loans.use: To buy sprays for his cattle to kill ticks, de-worming medicine to treat against diseases, and to purchase more cattle

loans.name: Cheang

texts.en:
Mrs. Cheang S., age 36, has established a small family home located in Kompong Tom province where she lives with other family members. Her family has four kids, two of whom are employed and the other two attend school.

To share responsibility for her family, Cheang S. owns a cart that she uses to sell bean juice in and around her community. She is able to make $4 of profit a day to be used to control the financial problems of her family. She always gets help from her husband in producing the bean juice.

Cheang S. wants to own a motorbike to connect with her existing cart so that she can sell to people farther away. As she doesn’t have the money to buy one, she needs a loan in the amount of $900 to buy a used motorcycle.

loans.use: To buy a used motorcycle for her business

loans.name: Abida's Group

texts.en:
Abida lives in Lahore, Pakistan’s second largest city. She is 29 years old and sews clothes for her neighboring clients to earn income of her family. She married at an early age and has three sons. Her eldest son also does sewing work along with his mother while her younger sons are receiving their education by going to school.

Abida lost her husband five years ago which was a big tragedy and loss of her life. She was completely lost but she regained her courage and started her sewing business to spend a normal life. Currently, she lives with her mother and 2 brothers who also do different kinds of work and contribute financially to the family.

Abida has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah, for her sewing business. With the loan, she will buy an electric sewing machine which will help her to sew more clothes in less time and to earn a good income as well. She is hopeful that, with the increased income, her children will be able to continue their education.

Abida is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 3rd loan. With her previous loans she has proved herself as a responsible client who always paid installments on time and never missed a meeting.

In the photo, Abida is the lady who is raising her hand.

loans.use: To buy an electric sewing machine for her business

loans.name: Nicholas

texts.en:
Nicholas O. W. is 28-years-old and married. His wife stays at home all day long taking care of their two children, aged five and two years old. Nicolas' business, located at an open air market called Kongowea in Mombasa, is well-known by the name Hasla Finess, selling trousers, shirts, dresses and jeans. His customers are both repeat customers and walk-ins. Nicholas says that this business is profitable and the only major challenge he faces is stiff competition from other vendors. He also says that the economy is bad, thereby reducing the volume of his sales. However, he works very hard from early morning to late evening to keep his business healthy.

Nicolas plans to use his loan of Kes 50,000 to buy more dresses, blouses, skirts and jeans in order to increase stock. He hopes to open more stalls to earn more income in the future. He describes himself as honest, trustworthy, and committed to his business.

loans.use: To purchase jeans, skirts, blouses and dresses.

loans.name: Catherine

texts.en:
Catharine N., who is 16 years old and lives in the town of Kyengera in the Kampala West region of Uganda, is single and has no children. Catherine has had a poultry business for five years, and she also has a brick-laying enterprise.

In order to expand, Catherine has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda to purchase chicken feed (maize brand) and more chicks. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Catherine hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees. In the future, she hopes to expand her business and own land.

Catherine is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by teaching her how to get enough capital for the future.

loans.use: To purchase chicken feed (maize brand)

loans.name: Felicima

texts.en:
A hardworking mother of four children, at age 65 Felicima S. B. still manages her canteen and fruits and vegetables retailing business. Three of her children are already employed, while the youngest is still studying. She is a member of Ahon sa HIrap, Inc. (ASHI) – a partner Microfinance Institution of KIVA in the Philippines since 2002. One of the most active members of ASHI- Rizal Central Branch, she serves as an inspiration to many women in the community in joining the program.

Today Felicima is applying for a loan of P40,000.00 in pesos as additional capital for her business in order to increase her customer base and her income. This will enable her to start saving, help her youngest daughter complete college, and continue to help her husband in their financial needs. Her business plan is to construct a much wider space for her canteen and establish a grocery for her children to continue as the couple grows older. She wants to hire people and provide employment, especially to those out-of school-youth so that they can earn for their schooling.

Felicima is so happy and keeps praying that ASHI and KIVA will continue their partnership in providing financial assistance to poor but deserving families.

loans.use: To buy additional fruits and vegetables both for the canteen and for retailing

loans.name: Jonathan

texts.en:
Jonathan is a married man with two children, both attending school. He lives in a rental house with electricity but no piped water. His greatest monthly expenses are rent and food.

Jonathan has been operating his motorcycle transport business (boda boda) for the last six months. His potential customers are passersby who need a ride.

Jonathan decided to work with Yehu so as to obtain a loan to boost his business. With the Kshs 20,000 he wants to pay a deposit for the purchase of another motorcycle. He cites seasonality as a major challenge in his business. His major goal is to own a car in the future.

loans.use: To pay a deposit for the purchase of another motorcycle

loans.name: Mrs. Toy Im Village Bank Group

texts.en: Mrs. Toy I., 63, is a village bank president, selected by eleven people in Rumchek village in Takeo province. They will use their portiO. of the loan for different purposes. She and her husband, Mr. Ken Kom, are farmers who own a 2.50-hectare plot of land where they cultivate rice to sell to support their famiL.. Her problem is that her field contains infertile soil. So, to improve productiO., Mrs. Toy I. is applying for a loan to buy fertilizer. With the rest of the loan, she will buy a bicycle. She is a mother of three children, two of whom are seamstresses in a garment factory, while the other is attending school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Caroline

texts.en:
Caroline N. is twenty-seven years old. She is single and has one child aged eight years old.

Caroline’s business is located at Juja, a very busy business market in Thika, a region in Kenya known for its production of pineapples. She has been selling cabbages for the last two years and has provided employment for one employee.

Caroline says that her business is profitable and the only major challenge she has is that there are very many people in the area doing the same kind of business as hers. Hence, customers are spoilt for choice. However, she works very hard to keep her business doing well.

Caroline is using her loan of Kes 15,000 to buy more cabbages to meet her customers demand. In the future, she hopes to be a supplier of cabbages in bulk to other towns. She also hopes to purchase a plot and build her own house. She says that she believes she is good in retaining her customers and is willing to really sacrifice her time for her business.

loans.use: To buy more cabbages to sell

loans.name: Norma

texts.en:
Norma G., 64 years old, is one of the pioneer members of Ahon sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI), a Kiva microfinance institution partner in the Philippines. She joined ASHI in 1999 and remains one of many loyal and active member of the institution.

Because of her performance, Norma has been rewarded with many loan benefits that she utilized in her business and in providing education for her two children. Her eldest is now a teacher and the youngest is a graduate of Business Management. She is so proud of her achievements, yet she is dreaming of more.

Norma is applying for another loan of PHP 45,000 as additional capital for her grocery (their primary source of income) and as finance for farm inputs. She will buy additional grocery products for her store, sacks of organic fertilizer for their rice and vegetables plantation and also pay labor for farm cultivation.

Norma hopes to increase her profit and her harvest in farming because she wants to earn more for her plan to establish a much bigger grocery. She also wants to help other people earn income by providing employment on their farm. Since she is getting older she also wants to earn for their health protection to enable them to live a longer life.

Norma is happy to have ASHI and Kiva as support for her capital needs. She hopes and prays that the support continues until she reaches all her dreams in life.

loans.use: To buy additional grocery products and farm inputs

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en: Gloria M. is from the village of Siempre Viva Norte. She is 53 years old and is married with four adult children. Gloria owns and operates a business providing motorcycle transport services, operating a tricycle. She has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month. In 2006, Gloria joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to repair her vehicle in order to provide better service. Gloria is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase tires and other accessories. This loan will be her 9th from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small-business entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase tires and other accessories

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 37-year-old married man living in Lebanon. He has been selling cars since 2007 after seeing the need for such business in his town. This type of business earns a good income for his family, for which he is the main income provider.

He works independently in his business: he purchase cars, does the needed maintenance on them and then he resell them. Today, he is requesting $1,200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to add to his savings to purchase another car and the needed equipment to renovate it and sell it at a good profit.

loans.use: To purchase another car to renovate and sell

loans.name: Josefelia

texts.en:
In 2000, Josefelia G. found an opportunity to acquire business capital. She joined ASHI and was inspired by the stories she heard of other poor women. She wanted to become successful like them so because of this opportunity, Josefelia was able to start a fishing business.  She has taken all the risk of running a business; she thought she could be successful because her husband is there to support her and because of a dream of having all her children graduate from college.

Josefelia hopes that her children never have to experience the hard life she and her husband had . She dreams of increased space for her fishing equipment and an expanded fishing business.  Josefelia’s main challenge has been having a small stock due to the hindrances of small working capital to put into her fishing business. Therefore, Josefelia needs a larger loan to expand her fishing business. The fish her husband catches are sold by Josefelia in their village and to people selling fish in the market. She thinks that commercializing her fishing business and expanding it will enable her to earn more revenue and be able to pay school fees for her children and provide for other family needs. Josefelia’s wish to give her children a brighter future fuels her commitment to her fishing business. 

With all of her plans for the growth of her business, Josefelia would be happy if her children are able to achieve their personal dreams and have a life free of poverty.

loans.use: To expand her fishing business.

loans.name: Mrs. Boek Sary Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan is made up of 16 people from Rumchek village in Takeo province. Mrs. Boek S. is the village bank president. The members of the group all hope the loan will improve their family's standard of living.
Mrs. Boek S., 41, and her husband, Mr. Nhor Ol, are farmers who own a 0.5-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to support their family. She is also a weaver while her husband is a barber. Since Mrs. Boek S.'s business is going well, she wants to expand it. Therefore, she is requesting a loan to buy more silk. She is a mother of two children, one of whom is a seamstress in a garment factory while the other is studying in school.

loans.use: To buy more silk

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence N. is 22 years old and lives in the town of Kyengera in the Kampala West region of Uganda.  She is single and has no children. Florence has a business of a retail shop, which she has had for 3 years.  Florence also has a business of a pay phone and phone air time.

To help expand her business, Florence has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase and stock sugar and maize flour.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Florence hopes to generate greater profits and buy food.  In the future, Florence hopes to own a plot and a house. 

Florence is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by boosting her businesses.

loans.use: buying sugar and flour for retail shop

loans.name: Lorena

texts.en: Lorena M. is a married woman who lives in Calumpang, Poblacion, Cauayan, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating two businesses: a general store and fish vending businesses. Her husband Melbert M., who is 41 years old, manages his own business to earn his living. They have two children who are 10 and 13 years old. Lorena joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1997 because she wanted something better for her family. With the help of her past 13 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Lorena has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 21,500 Philippine pesos (PHP) helped her earn a monthly profit of 10,000 PHP, raising the family's standard of living. This time, for her 14th loan, she is borrowing 25,000 PHP, which she intends to use to stock more things to sell in her general store. She wants to continue to save up for the future security of her family, for her children's education and family needs. Lorena M. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. About NWTF In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Expanding store inventory

loans.name: Mrs. Lach Kong Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan consists of fourteen people who live in Rumchek village in TaK. province. Mrs. Lach K., 55, is the village bank president selected by the other members who will use their portions of the loan for different purposes.

Mrs. Lach K. is a farmer who owns a 0.5-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to sell to support her family. She also sells Khmer noodles and desserts in the local village. Although Mrs. Lach K. works hard, she earns little money. To improve her family's living standards, she is seeking a loan to start a new business by buying some piglets for breeding. Mrs. Lach K. is a widow with two children: one is a rock breaker and the other is employed in a printing house.

loans.use: to buy some piglets for breeding

loans.name: Irene

texts.en:
Irene N. is 20 years old and lives in the town of Kyengera in the Kampala West region of Uganda.  She is married and has 3 children.  All of her children are currently in school.  Irene has a retail business, which she has had for less than one year.         

To help expand her business, Irene has requested a loan of 150,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more sugar and soap.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Irene hopes to generate greater profits and buy food.  In the future, Irene hopes to own a house. Irene is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by improving her business.

loans.use: buying sugar and soap for resale

loans.name: Pich

texts.en:
Mr. Pich D. is a middle-aged man and is married with two school-aged kids. Pich D. possesses a small workshop from which he provides a blacksmithing service to his nearby neighbors. 

He has employees who assist him in this business. He produces metal hammers, knives, hatchets, etc. Pich D. has another financial earner in his wife who plants crops to earn a living. In order to earn additional revenue, Pich D. has requested a loan to be used to book the plantation where the cashews grow. He estimates that he can harvest the cashews to sell when they are mature.

loans.use: purchasing a cashew harvest

loans.name: Emma

texts.en:
Emma J. a 52-year-old mother of four children and is married to a fisherman. Her two eldest daughters are employed as seamstresses while her sons help their father in fishing; the youngest is also studying. 

She is a very good and active member of Ahon sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI)--a partner Microfinance Institution of Kiva in the Philippines. She invested her previous loans in improving their fishing business, and the family benefited from the increase profit. 

She is applying for a new loan of 40,000 Philippine pesos to finance their business. Her husband wants to buy new sets of fishing nets, sets of “bobo” - a local fishing gear made of bamboo and netting to trap shrimp, and to repair their wooden bancas/boats. 

It will be of great help if she can purchase all this in time for the rainy season because fish are abundant in the Laguna Lake. This additional gear will again increases their profit and she can save for the future of her youngest who is still studying. She wants to send him to college so he can pursue a career. She also wants to buy additional appliances in the near future. 

She is optimistic that her dreams can soon be achieved, and she is proud for being a member of ASHI and Kiva, because she has had help in improving her family's living conditions through their financial assistance.

loans.use: buying fishing gear; repairing fishing boats

loans.name: Birugi

texts.en: Birugi N. is 20 years old and lives in the town of Kyengera in the Kampala west region of Uganda. She is married and has three children. All of her children are currently in school. For four years, Birugi has had a business of selling matooke. She also sells charcoal. To help expand her business, Birugi has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more matooke and charcoal. With the help of the loan, Birugi hopes to generate greater profits and buy food. In the future, Birugi hopes to see her children complete university. Birugi is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has improved her prospects for the future by increasing profit on her business.

loans.use: To buy more matooke and charcoal

loans.name: Musa

texts.en: Musa is a married man with no children. He has been operating a photocopier shop from home. For the past year his other source of income has been a green grocer stall at the market, and he also sells door to door and from home to his neighboring community. Musa cites transportation and seasonality as the major challenges in the business. With the KES 20,000 he wants to build a cyber café and pay for the business permit. He hopes to run the cyber café in the future. Musa decided to join Yehu so as to get a loan to change his business. Musa lives at a rental house with electricity but no piped water. His greatest monthly expenses are rent and food.

loans.use: To build a cyber cafe.

loans.name: Mrs. Mao Noun Village Bank Group

texts.en: This group loan is requested by fourteen people who live in Tboung Damrei village in Takeo province. Mrs. Mao N., who was born in 1973, has been selected by the other group members to be the leader. Each group member will use his/her portion of the loan for a different purpose. Mrs. Mao N. sells vegetables in the local market, which enables her to earn enough money to support her family. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand. To improve her current business, Mrs. Mao N. is applying for a loan to buy more vegetables to sell. She is a widow with three children, one of whom is a driver. Another is attending school, and the youngest is five years old.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables to sell

loans.name: Badamhorloo

texts.en: Badamhorloo B., 55, has six sons and one daughter, some of whom live separately from their parents. She lives with her husband and two adult-aged sons in Hovd province in western Mongolia. They live in their ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. Her oldest son, 26, serves in the Mongolian military force and is going to marry soon. Her youngest son, 22, currently stays at home. Her husband works as a herder in the countryside. Badamhorloo has been operating a raw materials trading business for past 12 years by purchasing a variety of cans, bottles, aluminum, etc. Over the years of successful business operation, her earnings have enabled her to buy a new car for herself. She started a taxi service in 2004 using her car. Badamhorloo is a very hardworking woman. She hopes to grow both of her businesses. She is requesting a 1,500,000 MNT loan to purchase more cans and aluminum for her raw material trading business.

loans.use: To purchase more cans and aluminum

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David is a farmer from Murang'a town in central Kenya. He has been farming for eighteen years and employs two farmhands. His mixed farm produces bananas, maize and beans which he sells at a local market. He is also employed.

David has requested this loan of 30,000 KES through Juhudi Kilimo to purchase a water tank. He says that, by storing rain water, this will help him save time and energy looking for water and will ensure the survival of his bananas during the dry seasons. His biggest challenge has been poor weather patterns that affects his production.

David is 48 years old and is married with one school-aged child.

loans.use: To purchase a water tank.

loans.name: Wifred

texts.en:
Thirty-three-year-old Wilfred is a married father of two children aged 4 and 8, both attending school. He is a farmer from Kitale town in western Kenya where he has been farming for eight years and employs one farmhand. He sells his milk, eggs, maize and vegetables at a local market. He is a full-time farmer and depends on the income from his farm to cater for the needs of his family.

Wilfred recently repaid his previous loan from Juhudi Kilimo and has requested this loan of 51,200 KES to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He says this loan will help improve the livelihood of his family since he will be able to provide them with enough milk for consumption and to pay school fees for his children with the income from the sale of milk.

Wilfred hopes that, in the future, he will be able to acquire four more dairy cows and four dairy goats and become the main milk supplier to the local market. His primary challenges are lack of storage facilities for his milk and the low price of milk.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Twunguranibitekerezo Group

texts.fr:
Emmanuel N., un des membres du groupe TWUNGURANIBITEKEREZO de sake dont les membres sont tous agriculteurs, il est marié et a 40 ans. Son niveau d’étude est primaire.
Il a 6 enfants, le premier a 16 ans et le cadet a 1an, trois des ses enfants vont a l’école.  Il  habite avec sa famille en district de Bugesera précisément à sake, en province de l’est. Il est agriculteur de riz,  il vient de contracter un prêt au sein d’Amasezerano pour augmenter l’argent de ses épargnes pour acheter les angrais chimiques. Ses épargnes lui ont permis de pouvoir acheter une vache, grâce à ces épargnes aussi elle fait vivre sa famille. Dans l’avenir elle veut continuer à mieux payer son prêt  afin de pouvoir bien tenir sa famille aisément et de stabiliser sa finance.
texts.en:
Emmanuel N. is 40 years old, married, and a member of TWUNGURANIBITEKEREZO group in Sake. All the members are farmers. He was educated at the elementary school level. He has 6 children. The oldest is 16 years old and the youngest is one year old. Three of his children go to school. He and his family live in the Bugesera district of Sake, in the Eastern Province. He is a rice farmer. He has just taken out a loan from Amasezerano to increase the amount of his savings so he can buy chemical fertilizers. His savings have enabled him to buy a cow. Thanks to these savings, he provides for his family. In the future he wants to continue to repay his loan so he will be able to provide for his family’s needs and stabilize its finances.

Translated from French by Connie Archea, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy chemical fertilizer, N.P.K

loans.name: Patrick

texts.en:
Patrick has been practicing mixed farming for six years in Kitale town, western Kenya. His mixed farm produces milk and maize which he sells to the local market; he has only one employee. He also earns income from his motorbike business. He faces the challenge of animal diseases which are too costly to treat.

Patrick is 25 years old. He is married and has no children.

Patrick has requested this loan of 61,200 KES through Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He says this loan will help improve the livelihood of his family since he will be able to provide enough milk for domestic consumption.

In five years time, Patrick hopes to have acquired five more dairy cows and be a major supplier of milk to the Kenya Cooperative Creameries.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Mrs. Bou Mach Village Bank Group

texts.en: Mrs. Bou M. was selected as the leader of a group of thirteen people in Tboung Damrei village in Takeo province seeking a loan. Each group member will use his/her portion of the loan for a different purpose. Mrs. Bou M., 47, sells rice and Khmer cake in a local market, which enables her to earn enough income to support her family. She is also a farmer: she owns a small piece of land on which she cultivates rice, which she sells. Because her rice business is going well, she wants to expand. She is seeking a loan to buy more rice to sell. She is a widow with two children. One is a seamstress in a garment factory, and the other is employed in a casino club.

loans.use: To buy more rice to sell

loans.name: Micah

texts.en:
Micah is the treasurer of Sise Tala-Tany group which is being funded by Juhudi Kilimo. He is a dairy farmer from the town of Litein in Rift Valley, Kenya, where he has been farming for three years and employs one farmhand. He sells his milk to the local market and also earns income from his small-scale farming of maize which he sells locally.

Micah is 28 years old and married with two children aged 2 and 4. His eldest child attends school.

Micah has requested this loan of 50,000 KES from Juhudi to purchase and insure a dairy cow. The extra income from this loan will help him pay school fees for his children and improve the livelihood of his family.

Micah would like to acquire a pure breed of dairy cows and build a dairy unit in future. His primary challenges are lack of enough animal feeds and diseases which are too costly to treat.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Meak

texts.en:
As everybody knows, fish paste is the main ingredient that Cambodian people use for cooking. Mrs. Meak S. became a fish trader in 1990. She always buys fresh fish and turns them into fish paste to either sell inside the market or around her community. She was busy at her business activities when the photo was taken, so her husband is pictured instead.

In addition to her business, Meak S. and her husband always take time to cultivate a rice crop during the farming season. They have eight children: two are already married and have started new homes, while the others are single.

Meak S. is concerned that her current income is not very much as her business has come to a low capacity due to insufficient capital. She wishes to increase her capital which will allow her to improve her profits. This is why she has decided to ask for a Kiva loan.

loans.use: To increase her capital which will allow her to improve her profits

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to perform maintenance and renovation for her house in order to rent it

loans.name: Sek

texts.en: Mrs. Sek S. is married, but has been divorced from her husband since her children were young. Sek S. currently lives with two of her children, while another one of her children is married and lives independently. To earn the money, Sek S. sells different types of fruit in the local busy market. Sek S. will be using the loan she requested to buy fruit from her wholesale supplier and resell them to raise income.

loans.use: To buy fruit from her wholesale supplier and resell them to raise income.

loans.name: Dashjargal

texts.en: Dashjargal B. is a 33 year old married woman with one daughter. She lives with her husband and daughter in Zavhan province of western Mongolia. Her daughter, 12, attends a local secondary school while her husband works as a carpenter. Her husband, Ochirdari, has owned his carpentry business for one year but he has earned the loyalty of his customers because of the quality of his work and service. He operates his business with his friend, therefore they divide earnings equally. Dashjargal herself operates a fruit and raw material trading businesses, both of which depend on season, in her town to supplement her family's income. Over the short period operation, her husband has quickly found success with his new business. He used his earnings to expand his business by purchasing necessary tools and equipments. Currently, they received a order of making two ger's furniture from neighbor sub province. For the future, he would like to have his own workplace. Dashjargal is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan in order to purchase more timber for her husband's growing business.

loans.use: To purchase more timber

loans.name: Charles

texts.en:
Charles is a dairy farmer from Litein town, Rift Valley, Kenya. He has been farming for 5 years and employs one farmhand. He sells his milk to the local market. He is also a businessman in the same location.

Charles is 26 years old. He is married with 3 children who are between the ages of 3 and 6. His eldest child attends school.

He has requested this loan through Juhudi Kilimo of the amount of 50,000KES to purchase and insure a dairy cow. The proceeds from this loan will help him pay school fees for his children. In future, he would like to acquire a pure breed of dairy cows and build a zero grazing unit. His biggest challenges are lack of enough animal feed and diseases. He is happy with the work of Juhudi.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Mrs. Saem Sok Lim Village Bank Group

texts.en: Twenty people who live in Tboung Damrei village in Takeo province are seeking a group loan. Each person will use a portion of the loan for different purposes. Mrs. SA. S. L., born in 1978, has been selected by the other members as the group leader. She is a farmer who owns a very small piece of land to cultivate rice, which she sells in order to support her family. Her husband buys and sells cows. His business is going well, and she wants to expand it. Therefore, she is requesting a loan to buy more cows to sell. She is the mother of two children who are enrolled in the local village school.

loans.use: To buy more cows to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Lesirko Ole

texts.en:
Lesirko Ole S. is 41 years old. He is married to Silole Sanamwala and is the father of five school-going children. He is a farmer and he farms his own piece of land which he has been doing for the last ten years.

Lesirko learned about KADET from other members in a group in his area already registered with KADET. This will be his first loan which he is planning to spend on preparing his land for planting wheat. Wheat has been doing well in his area due to the good climatic conditions. He hopes to use the profit from the proceeds of this loan to expand his farming activity from small-scale to commercial farming.

Lesirko’s dream is to become a large-scale farmer and to buy his own vehicle which will used to transport his farm produce to different markets. He is a hardworking man who is determined to achieve his set goals.

loans.use: To prepare land for planting wheat

loans.name: Amelita

texts.en:
Amelita S. is a 47-year-old married woman from Culasi in the province of Antique. She is blessed to have two children, both of whom are minors and need her support.

Amelita is a member of the Caridad center of Antique North Branch. She is a very strong-minded woman and she notes that she works hard to make their life quite meaningful. Despite trials brought about by poverty, she is still strong and dedicated in her pursuit to improve her family’s standard of living. Amelita’s main goal is to offer her two children a brighter future and that is what motivates her all day.

To make a good living, Amelita sells RTW (ready-to-wear-clothes) and has embarked on a livestock-raising business for added income. She has been engaged in these businesses for eight years.

Amelita joined ASHI, one of Kiva’s first partners in the Philippines, in 2002. During the course of her membership, she has been a good performer with regard to her attendance at center meetings, repayments, and her business.

Amelita is now requesting her new loan, this time in the amount of 25,000 PHP, to obtain additional stock for her RTW business and to support the needs of her secondary business of livestock raising. She is positive that, with access to additional working capital through Kiva partners, her dreams of building her own comfortable house will be achieved.

Amelita hopes that one day she will be able to have her own stall in the marketplace, instead of just in her house, from which to sell her RTW products; she wishes to be able to make enough savings to pay for her children's education and also wishes the best of life for her family. She also dreams of having an eatery business in the near future so that she can give an opportunity of employment to others.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory of ready-to-wear-clothes, and to support her livestock-raising business

loans.name: Feliza

texts.en:
Feliza A. is 67 years old and is a hardworking and strong mother. She is a widow and, being both father and mother at the same time, she took the responsibility of taking care of her six children.

Feliza joined Ahon sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI), a microfinance institution and Kiva partner in the Philippines, in 1996. ASHI played an important role in her dreams for her family and that’s why she maintains an outstanding performance as a member of the institution. She used the financial assistance that ASHI provided in her dressmaking business with which she earns her living. She was able to send her children to vocational school and support their daily needs. Today all her children have their own jobs.
 
As the years pass by, Feliza’s business continues to prosper and her number of customers is increasing. She is applying for another loan of 45,000 pesos to buy raw materials for her dressmaking business and to improve her sewing production space.

Feliza’s dream is to build a dress shop, to buy more sewing machines and to hire sewers to meet the demands of her customers. She wants to provide employment in their community to help eradicate poverty. She will save the profits from this loan to continue her business plan.

Feliza prays that ASHI and Kiva will continue to support her, not just in her business plan, but also in her good intentions.

loans.use: To buy raw materials for her dressmaking business and to improve her sewing production space

loans.name: Salome

texts.en:
Salome is a single woman who has been operating a greengrocer business for over ten years. She sells both wholesale and retail at the market and also from home to her neighbors.

With the Kshs 70,000, Salome wants to purchase a chainsaw to operate a timber-cutting business. She faces the major challenge of transportation in her business.

Salome hopes to open another greengrocer branch in the future. She decided to join Yehu so as to obtain a loan to sustain her and to improve her living standard. She rents a house with electricity and piped water, her greatest monthly expenses being house rent and food.

loans.use: To purchase a chainsaw for cutting timber for sale

loans.name: Shamim's Group

texts.en:
Shamim lives in Lahore, the second largest city in Pakistan. She is a 51-year-old housewife who spends most of her time staying at home and doing her household tasks. She is widow and lives with her son and brother in a two-room brick house in the Mughalpura area.

Shamim’s brother operates a motor workshop where he repairs motorbikes. Her son assists him in this business. Shamim has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah, for her brother’s business. With the loan, he will buy the latest repairing tools for his motor workshop to make his work more effective for his customers.

Shamim is a new loan applicant and she hopes the loan will bring positive changes to her brother’s business. She is hopeful that he will be able to make positive changes in his business by utilizing the loan in a proper way.

In the photo, Shamim is the lady who is raising her hand.

loans.use: To enable her brother to buy the latest repairing tools for his motor workshop

loans.name: Davaajantsan

texts.en: Davaajantsan T., 28 years old, lives with his wife and son in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent, in Hovd province in western Mongolia.  His wife works as a nurse for a hospital, while his son attends a local kindergarten.  Davaajantsan used to operate a taxi service but then he bought a new truck from his earnings and started a transportation business which he ran from 2005 to 2009. He currently operates a car repair business in his yard. An astute and business-minded man, Davaajantsan is requesting a 800,000 MNT loan in order to purchase some repair parts, tools and paint for his car repair center

loans.use: To purchase some repair parts and tools

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce, a farmer from the town of Murang'a in central Kenya, has been farming for 26 years and has one permanent employee and four casual laborers. Her mixed farm produces milk, which she sells through Kenya Cooperative Creameries, and coffee, which she sells through the Coffee Board of Kenya. She also earns income from her posho mill and through the sale of bananas to the local market.

Joyce has requested this loan of 63,600KES through Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. She says this loan will help increase her income and enable her to educate her son to the university level. She currently has two dairy cows producing six liters of milk daily but hopes her milk output will increase to over 30 liters daily in the near future. Joyce says the future is bright with Juhudi loans as she will be able to do farming as a business and create wealth for her family.

Joyce is 52 years old. She is married with four children, three adults and one 16-year-old who attends school.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Enhtuya

texts.en:
Enhtuya S. is 35 years old and lives with her husband and three children in the Hovd province in western Mongolia. Her oldest two children attend a local secondary school and her youngest stays at home. Her husband is a driver. 

Enhtuya operates a small grocery shop near her house. She sells a variety of food products to the residents in her neighborhood. She started her business in 2000 and has built a stable operation. She has a shamanism heritage and says, "I received a(n) order from heavens in my dreams that I should help my nation and therefore, I try my best for my nation's happiness."  

She is requesting a 2,500,000 Mongolian tugriks loan to enlarge her grocery shop.

loans.use: To enlarge her grocery shop

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand her poultry farm

loans.name: Zikriyo

texts.ru: Сайвалиев Зикриё проживает в районе Яван. Возраст, 60 лет. Женат, имеет 8 детей. Сыновья на заработках в России. Сам Зикриё имеет среднее образование. Более 7 лет занимается растениеводством. Имеет земельный участок, где сеет пшеницу и выращивает овощи. Кредит берет для закупа семян. На полученную прибыль хочет женить своего сына.
texts.en:
Zikriyo S. lives in the Yavan district. He si 60 years old, married and has 8 children. His sons work in Russia. Zikriyo has a secondary education. He has been involved in agriculture for over 7 years. He has a plot of land, where he sows wheat and grows vegetables. Zikriyo is requesting this loan for the purchase of seeds. He wants to use resulting profits to marry off his son.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of seeds

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Joseph Kinuthia

texts.en:
Joseph has run his butcher shop in Naivasha town for the last nine years.  He is 37 years old and married to Esther Wangeci. They have two children.

He was introduced to KADET LTD. by his friend and this will be his first loan. He plans to use the cash to build a food stall next to his butcher shop. This will increase his income.

Joseph wants to grow in the food sector in the future.  He would love it if he was able to run a chain of food stalls and also become a major supplier of meat in Naivasha town.

loans.use: To construct a food stall next to his butcher shop

loans.name: Ruth Wanjiku

texts.en:
Ruth Wanjiku K. is 36 years old and married to Paul Wanjohi. She supports seven members of her family. She is a farmer. She does the farming  activity on her own piece of land, which she has been doing for the last seven years.

She learned about KADET LTD. through an awareness campaign done by KADET staff in her area of residence. This will be her second loan. She is planning to spend 40,000 Kenyan shillings to buy fertilizer and pesticide to spray on her growing wheat. 

With the profits she hopes to make from the proceeds of this loan, she intends to plant wheat on a bigger piece of land.

Her future dream is that she will be able to buy a bigger piece of land where she will be doing commercial farming. 

She is a hardworking woman and very determined to achieve her set goals.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and pesticide to spray on her growing wheat

loans.name: Him

texts.en:
Mrs. Him V. has been spending almost all of her entire life in the farming business. She plants various crops to earn a living and typically generates an income of $2 per day. Her husband buys small blocks of wood and turns them into charcoal to sell, earning about $4 each day. 

The couple married many years ago, and they have a lovely young child who is enrolled in the public primary school. Him V. will be using her first loan for her husband to use to build another suitable location to produce charcoal.

loans.use: To build another suitable location to produce charcoal

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To start poultry farming.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To upgrade her poultry farm.

loans.name: Nyamsuren

texts.en:
Nyamsuren L. is 49 years old and lives with her husband and three children in the Uvurhangai province in central Mongolia. She lives with her family in a "ger," a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent home. Her oldest two children are students in Ulaanbaatar, a capital city of Mongolia. 

Nyamsuren operates a small cafe named "Dulguun" in her town. Her cafe specializes in making a variety of traditional Mongolian meals and is a popular dining establishment in her community. She started her cooking business in 1996 with help of her sibling by selling homemade meals in a local market and they have built a successful business over the years. 

They used their earnings to buy a small pavilion that they use as a cafe today. Her cafe is located in a crowded place at the local market that attracts a lot of customers. 

Nyamsuren is a very diligent and modest woman. She is requesting a 600,000 Mongolian tugriks loan to purchase necessary equipment and tools and to renovate her cafe.

loans.use: To purchase necessary equipment and tools

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Mrs. Phan Soun Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan has 13 people located in Angk Svay Chek village in the Takeo province. Mrs. P. S., 30, is the village bank president selected by the other members, who will use their portion of the loan for different purposes. 

She and her husband, Mr. Choem Hav, are farmers who own a more than 1-hectare plot of land in which to grow crops to sell to support their family. He is also a motor-taxi driver. 

Her problem is that it is time to grow crops in the field, but she does not have enough money to support planting. So, to improve production, Mrs. P. S. is seeking a loan to do farming. With the rest of the loan, she will buy fertilizer and gasoline. 

She is a mother of two children, both of whom are too young to work or study. The day of the loan disbursement, Mrs. P. S. was busy working in the field. Instead, her husband, Mr. Choem Hav, received the loan for her. The photo above includes Mrs. P. S.'s husband.

loans.use: To do farming

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a bundle of  wheat flour, maize flour, rice and kitchen utensils for sale

loans.name: Mrs. Nhav Yeang Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Nhav Y. was born in 1962. She will be the village bank president and was selected by 14 people who will use their portion of the loan for different purposes. They are located in Angk Svay Chek village in the Takeo province. 

She and her husband, Mr. Duon Nuon, are farmers who own a small piece of land in which to cultivate rice to sell to support their family. He is also a fisherman. At this time, she has some problems because her field has infertile soil. So, to improve production, Mrs. Nhav Y. is applying for a loan to buy fertilizer. With the rest of the loan, she will hire a plow machine to plow her field and hire farming laborers. 

She is the mother of two children, one of whom is a seamstress in garment factory, while the youngest one is attending school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Gulruhsor

texts.ru: Азизова Гулрухсор проживает в районе Яван. Возраст, 42 года. Замужем, имеет 3 детей. У мужа дехканское хозяйство. Сама Гулрухсор имеет среднее образование. Более 10 лет занимается растениеводством. Она в основном сеет пшеницу. Кредит берет для закупа семян.
texts.en:
Gulruhsor A. lives in the Yavan district. She is 42 years old, married and has 3 children. Her husband has a dekhan farm. Gulruhsor has a secondary education. She has been involved in agriculture for over 10 years. She primarily sows wheat. Gulruhsor is requesting this loan for the purchase of seeds.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of seeds

loans.name: Em

texts.en:
Mr. Em S. is a local chef who is hired by people to cook food for their wedding parties. Em S. is 41 years of age and is married to Mrs. Pailin, age 28, who generates income by working in a garment factory. This couple has two young kids who are going to school. 

Em S. currently has an older mother (pictured) who stays at home to arrange the daily routine. The family faces difficulties traveling to work or anywhere else because they have no vehicle. 

Em S. dreams of owning a vehicle and he has been trying to save up his money for a long time, but his savings are insufficient to buy one. Therefore, Em S. requests a loan to be able to afford to buy a new motorcycle.

loans.use: To afford to buy a new motorcycle

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more bags of rice, pepper, meat, fish, tomatoes, onions etc

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en:
Rehema S. is a married woman with two children who attend school. She has been operating a retail shop and she also sells second hand clothes.Her major customers are the neighboring community and passersby. Rehema faces the major challenge of seasonality in her business. She has no other source of income. Rehama owns a house with no electricity and no piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees.

Rehema's major aim in working with Yehu is to access loans to boost her business. With a loan of  Kshs 30,000,  Rehema wants to purchase a bale of clothes and stock of sugar, wheat flour, maize flour and cooking oil for her retail shop.

loans.use: To  purchase a bale of clothes and stock of sugar, wheat flour, maize flour and cooking oil for her retail shop.

loans.name: Kiteera Basubuzi Kweterana, Mubende Group

texts.en:
John T. is a 39 year old pharmacist who is hard working and determined. The married father of 4 children has been running a clinic and a medicine shop from Kiteera Trading Centre in Mubende District for close to 14 years. From this he is able to educate his children who are still attending different institutions of learning. 

With this loan, John wants to restock medicine business with more drugs. He hopes to turn it into a big pharmacy because his customer numbers have increased. This will enable him earn more revenue and also be able to sustain his family's requirements.

John belongs to the Kiteera Basubuzi Kweterana, Mubende Group.

loans.use: To purchase of more stock of drugs

loans.name: God Good Women Group

texts.en:
Mary N., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called God Good Women.  She is 35 years old, married, and has three children who are between the ages of three to eighteen years. She was only able to attend school through 5th grade due to financial constraints. 

For 10 years, she has been selling used clothes in Waterside Market down town Monrovia, Liberia. She plans to use her 6,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 30,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy more bags of used clothes. She describes herself as an easy-going woman whose dream is to improve her business.


In the photo that accompanies this profile, Gertrude is inset at lower right because she was absent when the photograph was taken.

loans.use: To buy more bags of used clothes

loans.name: Guldasta

texts.ru: Сафарова Гулдаста проживает в районе Яван. Возраст, 49 лет. Замужем, имеет 5 детей. Сын на заработках в России. Сама Гулдаста имеет среднее образование. Вместе с мужем занимается животноводством. Разводит скот в дальнейшем для перепродажи. Имеет хороший опыт в этой сфере. Кредит берет для закупа крупно - рогатого скота.
texts.en:
Guldasta S. lives in the Yavan district. She is 49 years old, married and has 5 children. Her son works in Russia. Guldasta has a secondary education. Together with her husband, she is involved in animal husbandry. She breeds livestock for future resale. She has a good experience in this field. Guldasta is requesting this loan for the purchase of cattle.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cattle

loans.name: Ekyerisho Traders, Mubende Group

texts.en: N. Asia, age 36, has been operating an agricultural farm from Ekyerisho Traders of Mubende for 1 year. There he grazes cattle and sells milk to earn his living. The married father of six children is hard working and looks forward to owning a bigger farm in the near future that will also allow him to sell some of his cattle for meat. N. is seeking a loan to help him purchase more cattle to restock his farm, in order to be able to earn more revenue out of his milk sales. With this, he will be able to cater to his family needs and educate his children.

loans.use: purchase of more cattle for milk production

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more cartons of used bags

loans.name: Mrs. Hul Thol Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Twelve people who live in Angk Svay Chek village in the Takeo province make up this village bank loan. They will use their portion of the loan for different purposes to improve their families' living standards. 

Mrs. Hul T., 54, is the village bank president who was selected by the other members. She is a farmer who owns a 1-hectare plot of land in which to cultivate rice to sell to support her family. She is also a fisherwoman. She has some problems because she does not have enough fishing supplies to use. So, to improve this condition, Mrs. Hul T. is asking for a loan to buy fishing net and a fishing boat. She is a widow who lives in a two-member household.

loans.use: To buy fishing net and a fishing boat

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Enhbold

texts.en: Enhbold S. is 47 years old married woman with two adult -age children. She lives in a ger, a traditional Mongolian housing tent, with her family in Huvsgul province of Mongolia. Her youngest son attends university. Her husband is a horse cart driver who transports loads to supplement his family's income. Enhbold operates a dairy trading business in her town. She purchases a large amount of dairy products from herders at wholesale prices and sells them back in a local market at retail prices. Enhbold has been engaged this business for 6 years and has built a stable operation. Over the years of operation, she has managed to expand her business and increase her product line which sells 10 types of dairy products. For the future, she hopes to grow her business by including other kinds of dairy products. Enhbold is a very modest and hardworking person. Her earnings have enabled her to pay her children's tuition fees. She is requesting a 600,000 MNT loan to purchase more dairy supplies from herders in order to increase her sales.

loans.use: To purchase more dairy supplies

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph E. is from the village of Poblacion, Don Carlos, Bukidnon. He is 43 years old. Joseph is married and has 1 school-age child. To make a living, Joseph owns & operates a business venture in the services sector operating a service-based business. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing public utility van services to local community members. Joseph has been engaged in his business for over 5 years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Joseph joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Joseph is requesting a  loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide service. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Joseph from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to provide service

loans.name: Abdalla

texts.en:
Abdalla  A. is a married man with three children who attend school. His wife is a businesswoman and she contributes to the family needs. Abdalla owns a house with electricity but no piped water. He has been operating his motorcycle business for the last two years from door to door. Abdalla's greatest monthly expenses are food and transport costs. He cites theft as his major challenge in the business. 

With the loan of Kshs 20,000, Abdalla wants to pay school fees and purchase motorcycle spare parts. 

Abdalla hopes to own a van for transport in future.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts for his motorcycle and also pay school fees.

loans.name: Irene Marie

texts.en:
Irene Marie B. is from the village of Poblacion, Don Carlos, Bukidnon. She is 34 years old. Irene Marie is married. To make a living, Irene Marie owns & operates a business venture in the food sector making & selling food.  The main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling snacks & other delicacies like hotcakes, banana cubes, and halo-halo,(a popular Filipino dessert that is a mixture of shaved ice and milk to which are added various boiled sweet beans and fruits, and served cold in a tall glass or bowl)  in the local community. Irene Marie has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Irene Marie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Irene Marie is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Irene Marie from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Depend On God Group

texts.en:
Fatu F., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called Depend On God. She is 48 years old, widowed and has five children whose ages are between 10 and 22 years. She was only able to attend school through twelfth grade due to a lack of financial support.

For 20 years, Fatu has been selling socks and earrings in downtown Monrovia, Liberia. She plans to use her 16,250 LRD portion of this 81,250 LRD group loan to buy more socks and earrings. She describes herself as a hard-working woman whose dream is to improve her business and continue her education.

loans.use: To buy more socks and earrings

loans.name: Ganchimeg

texts.en:
Ganchimeg T., a very modest and optimistic person, is 47 years old and lives with her husband and three sons in Uvurhangai province in western Mongolia. The family has been living in their own fenced ger, a traditional nomadic housing tent, for three years. Her oldest son, 23, is a student, while her middle son currently serves in the Mongolian military force. Ganchimeg's husband operates a transportation service and retail trading business in town.

Ganchimeg began her meat retailing business at the local market in 1996 with 100,000 MNT working capital that was a start-up loan from a bank. With her business revenues, she purchased the piece of land with a fence for her family’s ger. Ganchimeg is requesting 2,800,00 MNT to buy meat in bulk at a wholesale price so she can resell it at a higher price in winter when the price for meat traditionally rises.

loans.use: To buy meat in bulk

loans.name: Amer

texts.en:
Amer is a 34-year-old married man from Chtoura and is the father of three children. Amer has been creating stone sculpture pieces since 2000, and he's very brave in his work. His work is like art itself, and its creation requires good taste and a calm space in which to work. Amer loves his family a lot and seeks the best for them; he hopes he can help in giving them the education they deserve.

This is the first time Amer is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua, and he's asking for it in order to buy some things necessary to his business and to use what's left for school tuition fees. Amer hopes to expand his business in the future.

loans.use: To buy things necessary for his business and pay school tuition fees

loans.name: Maryjane

texts.en:
Maryjane G. is 52 years old, married and has two infant-aged children. She is from the village of Sampagar within the municipality of Damulog, a part of Bukidnon province on the Mindanao islands. Maryjane runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop from which she sells both food and daily use products to the local community. Maryjane has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Maryjane joined HSPFI to gain access to its financial services. She is requesting a loan, her first from HSPFI, of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that one-on-one translations of entrepreneur profiles are costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow it to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Mary Ann

texts.en:
Mary Ann C. is 32 years old, separated from her spouse and has two school-aged children. She is from the village of Sampagar within the municipality of Damulog, a part of Bukidnon province on the Mindanao islands. Mary Ann runs a specialized retail store from which she sells lotions and perfumes from a supplier in the local community. Mary Ann has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Mary Ann joined HSPFI to gain access to its financial services. She is requesting a new loan, her first from HSPFI, of 5000 PHP that will be used to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.
