loans.name: Sok

texts.en:
Mrs. Sok M., 49, runs a small business in which she sells incense inside the market. She also buys incense in bulk from her supplier to resell at a profit. To help meet family obligations, her husband works in construction.

Sok M. faces difficulty with transporting her items to sell because she doesn’t have her own vehicle. Therefore, Sok M. has decided to ask a loan from Kiva’s partner HKL in order to purchase a motorcycle which she will use for taking her incense to market and as the family’s means of transportation.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more bags of used clothes

loans.name: Eliza

To make a living, Eliza operates a tailoring business. The main source of income for the business comes from providing general alteration and tailoring services for local community members. Eliza has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 10,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2010, Eliza joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Eliza is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional fabrics and materials. This will be the first loan taken out by Eliza from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. texts.en: Mary Grace A. is from the village of Poblacion, Don Carlos, Bukidnon. She is 26 years old. Mary Grace is married and has an infant child. To make a living, Mary Grace sells personal products such as glasses, toys, silver-plated jewelries and watches in the local community. Mary Grace has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 3,500 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2010, Mary Grace joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mary Grace is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Mary Grace from HSPFI. loans.name: Josel

texts.en:
Josel M. is from the village of Angga-an, Damulog, Bukidnon. She is 24 years old. Josel is married and has two infant-aged children. To make a living, Josel owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting corn for sale. Josel has been engaged in the business for over two years and earns approximately 7500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Josel joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Josel is requesting a new loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to rent land to raise additional crops. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Josel from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand the borrower's business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: To rent land to raise additional crops

loans.name: Ismael

texts.en:
Ismael J., Jr. is from the village of Danggawan, Maramag, Bukidnon. He is 64 years old and married. To make a living, Ismael owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for sale. Ismael has been engaged in his business for over 10 years and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Ismael joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ismael has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future. Ismael is requesting a new loan of 13,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Ismael from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand his business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Vilma

texts.en:
Vilma B. is from the village of Danggawan, Maramag, Bukidnon. She is 57 years old and married. To make a living, Vilma owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Vilma has been engaged in her business for over 38 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Vilma joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Vilma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 25,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Vilma is requesting a new loan of 30,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. This loan will be the 11th loan taken out by Vilma from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory & working capital

loans.name: Laurd

texts.fr:
Jeune monsieur de 47 ans ; marie et père de 2 enfants dont l’âge varie entre 15 et 25 ans. N’ayant pas pu faire des longues études , par manque de soutien ; il s’inscrit dans un atelier de formation a la menuiserie.
A la fin de sa formation, il ouvre un atelier de menuiserie en 1982, tres entreprenant ; il a une grande clientèle et fait sont travail avec rapidité et beaucoup de sérieux. Il a des ventes par semaine de 50000frs a 450000frs. 

Avec le prêt qu’il compte recevoir il va acheter des planches comme  contres plaques, des bastings, des lattes, des pointes, de la colle et tous ce dont on a besoin pour fabriquer des meubles.

Très ambitieux, il a des grands projets pour son avenir, ouvrir un grand atelier et un magasin d’exposition de ses meubles  et en plus soutenir ses enfants pour faire des études universitaires et penser à construire une grand maison pour sa famille.
texts.en:
Laurd T. is 47 years old, married and the father of 2 children, 15 and 25 years old. Not being able to stay in school for very long because of lack of means, he enrolled in a woodworking training workshop. In 1982, at the end of his training, he opened a woodworking workshop. Very enterprising, he has a large clientele and does his work quickly and very responsibly. His weekly sales range from 50,000 to 450,000 francs. With the loan that he expects to receive, he is going to buy boards, such as plywood, beams, lathes, nails, glue and everything needed to build furniture. Very ambitious, he has big plans for the future: to open a large workshop and a furniture display shop. He also plans to support his children while they obtain a university education and to think about building a large house for his family.

Translated from French by Connie Archea, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy boards, beams, plywood, lathes, glue and nails

loans.name: Mirimu

texts.en:
Mirimu N. is 21 years old and lives in the town of Kyengera in the Kampala West region of Uganda. She is married and has three children. All of her children are currently in school. Mirimu has a business Retail shop, which she has had for 1 year. She also sells produce like maize flour

To help expand her business, Mirimu has requested a loan of 300,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase maize flour. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Mirimu hopes to generate greater profits and to buy food. In the future, Mirimu hopes to own a car. Mirimu is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by being able to easily pay back her loans because the rents are low.

loans.use: To buy more maize flour

loans.name: Emelie

texts.en:
Emelie B. is 29 years old, married and has two school-aged children. She is from the village of Port Area, a part of Iligan City on the Luzon islands. Emelie runs a business in which she makes and sells specialty food dishes like sotanghon to the local community. Emelie has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Emelie joined HSPFI to gain access to its financial services. Emelie successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from HSPFI that was used to purchase ingredients needed to make her food specialties. Emelie is requesting a new loan of 11000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to further expand her business.

About HSPFI:

location.town: Port Area, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Samer

texts.en:
Samer is a 38-year-old married man living in Bint Jbeil with his wife and two children. Samer has worked as an electrician (known as “the electricity man” in his town) since 2006. Samer works hard and seeks perfection in everything he does.

This is the first time that Samer is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua, and it's for multiple purposes. Samer needs to buy necessary tools for his business, to help his brother with his wedding and to pay for his children’s school supplements and tuition fees. Samer is happy for his brother and wants to help him to have the best wedding ever. He hopes to get this loan as soon as possible as he also wants to expand his business in the future.

loans.use: For tools for his business, for his brother's wedding and for school fees.

loans.name: Janat

texts.en:
Janat N. is 21 years old, married and has three children. All of her children are currently in school. She lives in the town of Kyengera in the Kampala West region of Uganda. Janat makes bricks, which she has done for over ten years. She also sells vegetables.

To help expand her business, Janat has requested a loan of 200,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase firewood for burning the bricks. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Janat hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees.

In the future, Janat hopes to see her children prosper through education. Janat is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by teaching her how to save.

loans.use: To buy firewood

loans.name: God Time Is The Best Group

texts.en:
Sekou D., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called God Time Is The Best. He is 23 years old, single and has one child who is one year old. He was only able to attend school through twelve grade due to financial constraints. He cares for one sibling.

For four years he has been operating a foreign exchange bureau in waterside downtown Monrovia, Liberia. He plans to use his 16,250 Liberian Dollars portion of this 81,250 Liberian Dollars group loan to add more money to his business. He describes himself as a devoted man whose goals are to improve his business and continue his education further.

loans.use: To add more money to his business

loans.name: Hasifah

texts.en:
Hasifah N. is 21 years old and lives in the town of Kyengera in the Kampala West region of Uganda. She is married and has three children.  One of her children is currently in school. Hasifah has a business in a food market, which she has had for one year. Hasifah also sells charcoal.

To help expand her business Hasifah has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more food and charcoal. With the help of the loan from BRAC Hasifah hopes to generate greater profits and buy more food. In the future Hasifah hopes to own another business, like a retail shop. Hasifah is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by increasing the number of items for sale in her business.

loans.use: To buy matooke and charcoal

loans.name: Purita

texts.en:
Purita S. is from the village of Rogongon, Iligan City. She is 56 years old. Purita is married and has two adult children. To make a living Purita owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income of the business comes primarily from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Purita has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010 Purita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Purita is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Purita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

location.town: Rogongon, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Anzhela

texts.en:
Anzhela G. was born in 1967 in Ljevan City. She is married, but her husband works and lives in Russia. Anzhela’s daughter is married and lives separately from her mother, and Anzhela’s son is a student in Yerevan. 

Two years ago Anzhela started her own business: selling clothing, which she run at rented shop at one of Ijevan’s central streets. Thanks to her business incomes Anzhela support her family and pays for her son’s education. 

Anzhela asks for a 550.000 Armenian Drams loan to buy an autumn clothes assortment for resell.

loans.use: To buy an autumn clothes assortment for resell

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia G. is from the village of Masilakon I, Lugait, Misamis Oriental. She is 58 years old. Lydia is married and has 2 adult-aged children. To make a living, Lydia owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling seafood products including fish and shrimp in the local community. Lydia has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 4500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Lydia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lydia is requesting a new loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional fishes to sell. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Lydia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional fish to sell

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more garments and school uniforms to sell

loans.name: Nelibeth

texts.en:
Nelibeth T. is from the village of Rogongon, Iligan City. She is 23 years old. Nelibeth is married and has 1 infant-aged child. To make a living, Nelibeth owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both snacks and fruit products in the local community. Nelibeth has been engaged in her business for over 1 year and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Nelibeth joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nelibeth is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Nelibeth from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

location.town: Rogongon, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Hassan

texts.en: Hassan is a 44 years old married man from Bint Jbeil and father of 4 children. Hassan has worked  in car repairs for 20 years. His major business is  changing car lubricants and repairing the cars air conditionners. Hassan is requesting a loan for the first time from Al Majmoua in order to increase the business capital. His clients like his work a lot. He hopes to expand his business to let his children benefit from it.

loans.use: To increase his capital

loans.name: Ablanvi

texts.fr: K. est un jeune homme de 22 ans, il est célibataire, pour subvenir à ses propres charges il s'est lancé dans la vente de maillots et de chaussures de sport. il réalise de bonnes recettes surtout en fin de semaine parce que les weekend les gens pratiquent les activités sportives. il a commencé la vente de maillots en 2007. sa clientèle se compose de toutes personnes. il sollicite de WAGES un premier crédit pour gonfler son stock avec 15 complets de maillots et 20 paires de chaussures.
texts.en:
K. is a young, 22-year-old, single man. He earns a living selling jerseys and sneakers. He makes good money, especially on weekends as people engage in sports activities. He started this business in 2007. His customer base is very diverse. He is seeking his first loan from WAGES to increase his stocks with 15 jerseys and 20 pairs of shoes.

Translated from French by Nathalie Pelletier, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy jerseys and shoes

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia N. is 19 years old and lives in the town of Kyengera in the Kampala West region of Uganda.  She is single and has no children. Lydia has a business of stone quarrying, which she has had for less than one year.         

To help expand her business, Lydia has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more stones.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Lydia hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees.  In the future, Lydia hopes to continue with her studies and complete university. Lydia is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by being able to change to a new life (thus buying new clothes. etc).

loans.use: To buy more stones

loans.name: Josiah Muriithi

texts.en:
Josiah Muriithi N. is a sole proprietor businessman who has been rearing pigs and practicing horticultural farming in Gichugu Mwea since the year 2006. He is married to Lucy Wangari, who is a teacher. This is also an additional source of income for the family. They are blessed with three children.

Josiah had borrowed from another microfinance institution (SMEP). He was introduced to KADET LTD. by KADET staff and he is applying for his first loan of 15,000 Kenyan shillings to buy three piglets and the feeds for the piglets. His business is situated where most people are middle-class and where butcher owners come around to buy more pigs for slaughter. 

With the extra income, he plans to grow his business to become self-sustainable. He hopes to settle his family in a plot of land of their own, where he can have the liberty to use and expand his business. He is able to meet the basic needs of his family, says Josiah.

loans.use: To buy three piglets and feeds

loans.name: United We Stand Group

texts.en: Fallah T., holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called United We Stand. He is 48 years old, married, and has seven children between the ages of 30 and 16. He was not able to attend school due to lack of financial support. For 20 years, he has sold door locks, hinges, cutlasses, knives, nails etc. in West point Market, down town Monrovia, Liberia. He plans to use his 27,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 72,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to increase his inventory. He describes himself as a determine man whose dream is to improve his business and continue to educate his children.

loans.use: To increase inventory

loans.name: Bendetta Mbevo

texts.en:
Benedetta N. is a 40 year-old married lady and the mother of three children — 27, 22 and 17. She is a greengrocer who sells vegetables and fruit. She has been in this business for five years and takes home a monthly income of 8,400 Ksh. She also gets additional income from her husband who is a farmer.

Bendetta is a new KADET client, applying for her first loan which she plans to use to add more fruit and green vegetables. The profits received from this boost will be banked as savings for the family. Bendetta is very hardworking and she hopes to increase the capacity of the business and move it to wholesale level.

loans.use: buying more stock of green vegetables and fruit

loans.name: Affi

texts.fr: affi est une dame de 42 ans, elle est mariée et a une personne à sa charge, elle vit avec sa famille dans le quartier de bè qui est quartier périphérique de la ville de Lomé, elle exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de produits d'alimentation générale et de boissons. elle a une ancienneté de 3 ans dans ce commerce et s'approvisionne au grand marché de Lomé; sa clientèle se compose de toutes personnes. Elle a appelé sa boutique "NIGHT TRAIN". elle voudrait s'approvisionner par l'achat de 2 cartons de Lait, 2 cartons de sardines, 2 cartons de macaroni, des casiers de boissons et divers.
texts.en:
Affi is a 42-year old woman, married with one dependent. She lives with her family in the Bè district, one of the peripheral districts of Lomé. She makes a living by selling general food products and beverages. She has been in this business for 3 years. She stocks up at the big market of Lomé. Her customer base is very diverse. She has named her store “Night train.” She would like to replenish her stock by buying two boxes of milk, two boxes of sardines, two boxes of pasta, some beverage cases etc.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing general food products

loans.name: Group For Used Shoes

texts.en:
Solomon G., holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called Group For Used Shoes. He is 40 years old, married, and has three children between the age of five and sixteen. He was not able to attend school due to lack of financial support. 

For five years, he has sold used shoes on Broad Street, down town Monrovia, Liberia. He plans to use his 15,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 57,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy more bags of used shoes. He describes himself as a determine man whose goals are to expand his business and continue to educate his children.

loans.use: To buy more bags of used shoes

loans.name: Rehen

texts.en: Rehen B. is in the business of selling rice and beans. She is requesting a loan to stock more of her current goods to sell. Rehen is 45 years old and married with a husband who is a farmer. She has five children all of whom go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a big shop.

loans.use: Stock more of her current goods to sell

loans.name: Progress Family Group

texts.en:
Thomas T., holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called Progress Family. He is 42 years old, married, and has seven children between the ages of 8 and 25. He was not able to attend school due to lack of financial support. 

For seven years, he has sold door locks, toothbrushes, shoes polish, soap etc. in Via Town Market, Monrovia, Liberia. He plans to use his 5,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 41,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to increase his inventory. He describes himself as a friendly man whose goals are to improve his business and continue to educate his children.

loans.use: To increase inventory

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan N. is 19 years old and lives in the town of Kyengera in the Kampala West region of Uganda.  She is single and has no children.  Susan has a business of tailoring, which she has had for 2 years.  She also rears chickens.  

To help expand her business, Susan has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more materials (cloth).  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Susan hopes to generate greater profits and sometimes buy food.  

In the future, Susan hopes to spend more on her business and own a car and a house. Susan is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future since she can repay the money on time because the interest rent is low.

loans.use: to buy more materials such as cloth

loans.name: Betty

texts.en: Betty D. is currently in the business of selling foodstuffs in small restaurant and is requesting a loan to stock more foodstuffs to sell.  Betty is 37 years old and is married to a husband who is a farmer. She has six children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand her restaurant.

loans.use: Stock more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Résurrection Plus Group

texts.en:
Baba M. is a leader of the community bank named “Résurrection Plus” which is composed of 16 micro-entrepreneurs united in solidarity to obtain loans from Kiva through the MFI HOPE DRC with the goal of developing their businesses. 

Baba sells salted and smoked fish in the western area of Kinshasa. She has been in business since 1994. Her beginning capital was US$ 80. Currently, through her sales, Baba makes about US$ 60 per week. Baba plans to use the next loan to purchase a bag of salted fish and some bags of smoked fish to resell in order to increase her income. She is a trustworthy client of the MFI Hope DRC, having six times received and properly repaid loans. She dreams one day to become a big fish provider in her area. Baba is 52 years old, married and a mother of five children whose ages are between 13 and 31. Three of them attend school.

loans.use: purchasing a bag of salted fish and some bags of smoked fish

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Fadeda

texts.en: Fadeda S. is currently in the business of selling wax and shoes  and is requesting a loan to stock more shoes to sell.  Fadeda is 24 years old and is married to a husband who is a driver. She has three children and one of her children goes to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a shop.

loans.use: Stock more shoes to sell

loans.name: Susan

texts.en: Susan Faida is currently in the business of selling dried fish  and is requesting a loan to stock more dried fish to sell.  Susan is 25 years old and is married to a husband who is a policeman. She has four children and three of  her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay the school fees for her children.

loans.use: Stock more dried fish to sell

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more bags of ladies' underclothes, dresses and head-ties

loans.name: Simeo

texts.en:
Hard-working R. Simeo has been operating an agro produce sales business in Kyengando village, Ibanda for a period of over 20 years. With nostalgia, this happily married father of four children recalls how his business basked in high profit returns at its onset. Times have changed, however, as the business now is in diminishing returns earning him 200,000 Ugandan shillings in sharp contrast to the previous earnings due seasonal changes.

Simeo is no exception in terms of doing business. What he is looking forward to now is the prospect of enhancing his business by buying fertilizer and improving production of bananas and coffee which he grows the most of. Under the auspices of this loan, he will improve on business expansion and production through mulching the plantations. He hopes to improve his revenue and also make himself more able to meet his day-to-day family necessities.

loans.use: buying fertilizer and mulch
